Theory Introduction

chapter‚ÄπA Gentle Introduction to TESL‚Ä∫

(*<*)
theory Introduction
  imports Main
begin

(*>*)

section ‚ÄπContext‚Ä∫
text‚Äπ
The design of complex systems involves different formalisms for modeling their different parts or 
aspects. The global model of a system may therefore consist of a coordination of concurrent 
sub-models that use different paradigms such as differential equations, state machines, 
synchronous data-flow networks, 
discrete event models and so on, as illustrated in \autoref{fig:het-timed-system}. 
This raises the interest in architectural composition languages 
that allow for ``bolting the respective sub-models together'', along their various interfaces, and 
specifying the various ways of collaboration and coordination~@{cite "nguyenvan:hal-01583815"}.

We are interested in languages that allow for specifying the timed coordination of subsystems by 
addressing the following conceptual issues:
‚ñ™ events may occur in different sub-systems at unrelated times, leading to ‚àó‚Äπpolychronous‚Ä∫ systems, 
  which do not necessarily have a common base clock,
‚ñ™ the behavior of the sub-systems is observed only at a series of discrete instants, and time 
  coordination has to take this ‚àó‚Äπdiscretization‚Ä∫ into account,
‚ñ™ the instants at which a system is observed may be arbitrary and should not change its behavior 
  (‚àó‚Äπstuttering invariance‚Ä∫),
‚ñ™ coordination between subsystems involves causality, so the occurrence of an event may enforce 
  the occurrence of other events, possibly after a certain duration has elapsed or an event has 
  occurred a given number of times,
‚ñ™ the domain of time (discrete, rational, continuous. . . ) may be different in the subsystems, 
  leading to ‚àó‚Äπpolytimed‚Ä∫ systems,
‚ñ™ the time frames of different sub-systems may be related (for instance, time in a GPS satellite 
  and in a GPS receiver on Earth are related although they are not the same).
‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
\begin{figure}[htbp]
 \centering
 \includegraphics{glue.pdf}
 \caption{A Heterogeneous Timed System Model}
 \label{fig:het-timed-system}
\end{figure}‚Ä∫

(*<*)
‚Äï ‚ÄπConstants and notation to be able to write what we want as Isabelle terms, not as LaTeX maths‚Ä∫
consts dummyInfty    :: ‚Äπ'a ‚áí 'a‚Ä∫
consts dummyTESLSTAR :: ‚Äπ'a‚Ä∫
consts dummyFUN      :: ‚Äπ'a set ‚áí 'b set ‚áí 'c set‚Ä∫
consts dummyCLOCK    :: ‚Äπ'a set‚Ä∫
consts dummyBOOL     :: ‚Äπbool set‚Ä∫ 
consts dummyTIMES    :: ‚Äπ'a set‚Ä∫ 
consts dummyLEQ      :: ‚Äπ'a ‚áí 'a ‚áí bool‚Ä∫

notation dummyInfty    (‚Äπ(_‚áß‚àû)‚Ä∫ [1000] 999)
notation dummyTESLSTAR (‚ÄπTESL‚áß*‚Ä∫)
notation dummyFUN      (infixl ‚Äπ‚Üí‚Ä∫ 100)
notation dummyCLOCK    (‚Äπùí¶‚Ä∫) 
notation dummyBOOL     (‚Äπùîπ‚Ä∫) 
notation dummyTIMES    (‚ÄπùíØ‚Ä∫) 
notation dummyLEQ      (infixl ‚Äπ‚â§‚á©ùíØ‚Ä∫ 100)
(*>*)

text‚Äπ
In order to tackle the heterogeneous nature of the subsystems, we abstract their behavior as clocks. 
Each clock models an event, i.e., something that can occur or not at a given time. This time is measured 
in a time frame associated with each clock, and the nature of time (integer, rational, real, or any 
type with a linear order) is specific to each clock. 
When the event associated with a clock occurs, the clock ticks. In order to support any kind of 
behavior for the subsystems, we are only interested in specifying what we can observe at a series 
of discrete instants. There are two constraints on observations: a clock may tick only at an 
observation instant, and the time on any clock cannot decrease from an instant to the next one. 
However, it is always possible to add arbitrary observation instants, which allows for stuttering 
and modular composition of systems. 
As a consequence, the key concept of our setting is the notion of a clock-indexed Kripke model: 
@{term ‚ÄπŒ£‚áß‚àû = ‚Ñï ‚Üí ùí¶ ‚Üí (ùîπ √ó ùíØ)‚Ä∫}, where @{term ‚Äπùí¶‚Ä∫} is an enumerable set of clocks, @{term ‚Äπùîπ‚Ä∫} 
is the set of booleans ‚Äì used to  indicate that a clock ticks at a given instant ‚Äì and @{term ‚ÄπùíØ‚Ä∫} 
is a universal metric time space for which we only assume that it is large enough to contain all 
individual time spaces of clocks and that it is ordered by some linear ordering @{term ‚Äπ(‚â§‚á©ùíØ)‚Ä∫}.
‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  The elements of @{term ‚ÄπŒ£‚áß‚àû‚Ä∫} are called runs. A specification language is a set of 
  operators that constrains the set of possible monotonic runs. Specifications are composed by 
  intersecting the denoted run sets of constraint operators.
  Consequently, such specification languages do not limit the number of clocks used to model a 
  system (as long as it is finite) and it is always possible to add clocks to a specification. 
  Moreover, they are ‚àó‚Äπcompositional‚Ä∫ by construction since the composition of specifications 
  consists of the conjunction of their constraints.
‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  This work provides the following contributions:
  ‚ñ™ defining the non-trivial language @{term ‚ÄπTESL‚áß*‚Ä∫} in terms of clock-indexed Kripke models, 
  ‚ñ™ proving that this denotational semantics is stuttering invariant,
  ‚ñ™ defining an adapted form of symbolic primitives and presenting the set of operational 
    semantic rules,
  ‚ñ™ presenting formal proofs for soundness, completeness, and progress of the latter.
‚Ä∫

section‚ÄπThe TESL Language‚Ä∫
   
text‚Äπ
  The TESL language @{cite "BouJacHarPro2014MEMOCODE"} was initially designed to coordinate the
  execution of heterogeneous components during the simulation of a system. We define here a minimal
  kernel of operators that will form the basis of a family of specification languages, including the
  original TESL language, which is described at \url{http://wdi.supelec.fr/software/TESL/}.
‚Ä∫  

subsection‚ÄπInstantaneous Causal Operators‚Ä∫
text‚Äπ
  TESL has operators to deal with instantaneous causality, i.e., to react to an event occurrence
  in the very same observation instant.
  ‚ñ™ ‚ñ©‚Äπc1 implies c2‚Ä∫ means that at any instant where ‚ñ©‚Äπc1‚Ä∫ ticks, ‚ñ©‚Äπc2‚Ä∫ has to tick too.
  ‚ñ™ ‚ñ©‚Äπc1 implies not c2‚Ä∫ means that at any instant where ‚ñ©‚Äπc1‚Ä∫ ticks, ‚ñ©‚Äπc2‚Ä∫ cannot tick.
  ‚ñ™ ‚ñ©‚Äπc1 kills c2‚Ä∫ means that at any instant where ‚ñ©‚Äπc1‚Ä∫ ticks, and at any future instant, 
    ‚ñ©‚Äπc2‚Ä∫ cannot tick.
‚Ä∫

subsection‚ÄπTemporal Operators‚Ä∫
text‚Äπ
  TESL also has chronometric temporal operators that deal with dates and chronometric delays.
  ‚ñ™ ‚ñ©‚Äπc sporadic t‚Ä∫ means that clock ‚ñ©‚Äπc‚Ä∫ must have a tick at time ‚ñ©‚Äπt‚Ä∫ on its own time scale.
  ‚ñ™ ‚ñ©‚Äπc1 sporadic t on c2‚Ä∫ means that clock ‚ñ©‚Äπc1‚Ä∫ must have a tick at an instant where the time 
    on ‚ñ©‚Äπc2‚Ä∫ is ‚ñ©‚Äπt‚Ä∫.
  ‚ñ™ ‚ñ©‚Äπc1 time delayed by d on m implies c2‚Ä∫ means that every time clock ‚ñ©‚Äπc1‚Ä∫ ticks, ‚ñ©‚Äπc2‚Ä∫ must have 
    a tick at the first instant where the time on ‚ñ©‚Äπm‚Ä∫ is ‚ñ©‚Äπd‚Ä∫ later than it was when ‚ñ©‚Äπc1‚Ä∫ had ticked.
    This means that every tick on ‚ñ©‚Äπc1‚Ä∫ is followed by a tick on ‚ñ©‚Äπc2‚Ä∫ after a delay ‚ñ©‚Äπd‚Ä∫ measured
    on the time scale of clock ‚ñ©‚Äπm‚Ä∫.
  ‚ñ™ ‚ñ©‚Äπtime relation (c1, c2) in R‚Ä∫ means that at every instant, the current time on clocks ‚ñ©‚Äπc1‚Ä∫
    and ‚ñ©‚Äπc2‚Ä∫ must be in relation ‚ñ©‚ÄπR‚Ä∫. By default, the time lines of different clocks are 
    independent. This operator allows us to link two time lines, for instance to model the fact
    that time in a GPS satellite and time in a GPS receiver on Earth are not the same but are 
    related. Time being polymorphic in TESL, this can also be used to model the fact that the
    angular position on the camshaft of an engine moves twice as fast as the angular position 
    on the crankshaft~‚Åã‚ÄπSee \url{http://wdi.supelec.fr/software/TESL/GalleryEngine} for more details‚Ä∫. 
    We may consider only linear arithmetic relations to restrict the problem to a domain where 
    the resolution is decidable.‚Ä∫

subsection‚ÄπAsynchronous Operators‚Ä∫
text‚Äπ
  The last category of TESL operators allows the specification of asynchronous relations between
  event occurrences. They do not specify the precise instants at which ticks have to occur, 
  they only put bounds on the set of instants at which they should occur.
  ‚ñ™ ‚ñ©‚Äπc1 weakly precedes c2‚Ä∫ means that for each tick on ‚ñ©‚Äπc2‚Ä∫, there must be at least one tick
    on ‚ñ©‚Äπc1‚Ä∫ at a previous or at the same instant. This can also be expressed by stating
    that at each instant, the number of ticks since the beginning of the run must be lower or 
    equal on ‚ñ©‚Äπc2‚Ä∫ than on ‚ñ©‚Äπc1‚Ä∫.
  ‚ñ™ ‚ñ©‚Äπc1 strictly precedes c2‚Ä∫ means that for each tick on ‚ñ©‚Äπc2‚Ä∫, there must be at least one tick
    on ‚ñ©‚Äπc1‚Ä∫ at a previous instant. This can also be expressed by saying that at each instant, 
    the number of ticks on ‚ñ©‚Äπc2‚Ä∫ from the beginning of the run to this instant, must be lower or 
    equal to the number of ticks on ‚ñ©‚Äπc1‚Ä∫ from the beginning of the run to the previous instant.
‚Ä∫


(*<*)
no_notation dummyInfty      (‚Äπ(_‚áß‚àû)‚Ä∫ )
no_notation dummyTESLSTAR   (‚ÄπTESL‚áß*‚Ä∫)
no_notation dummyFUN        (infixl ‚Äπ‚Üí‚Ä∫ 100)
no_notation dummyCLOCK      (‚Äπùí¶‚Ä∫) 
no_notation dummyBOOL       (‚Äπùîπ‚Ä∫) 
no_notation dummyTIMES      (‚ÄπùíØ‚Ä∫) 
no_notation dummyLEQ        (infixl ‚Äπ‚â§‚á©ùíØ‚Ä∫ 100)


end
(*>*)

Theory TESL

(*chapter‚ÄπThe Core of the TESL Language: Syntax and Basics‚Ä∫*)
text‚Äπ\chapter[Core TESL: Syntax and Basics]{The Core of the TESL Language: Syntax and Basics}‚Ä∫

theory TESL
imports Main

begin

section‚ÄπSyntactic Representation‚Ä∫
text‚Äπ
  We define here the syntax of TESL specifications.
‚Ä∫

subsection‚ÄπBasic elements of a specification‚Ä∫
text‚Äπ
  The following items appear in specifications:
  ‚ñ™ Clocks, which are identified by a name.
  ‚ñ™ Tag constants are just constants of a type which denotes the metric time space.
‚Ä∫

datatype     clock         = Clk ‚Äπstring‚Ä∫
type_synonym instant_index = ‚Äπnat‚Ä∫

datatype     'œÑ tag_const =  TConst   (the_tag_const : 'œÑ)         (‚ÄπœÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t‚Ä∫)


subsection‚ÄπOperators for the TESL language‚Ä∫
text‚Äπ
  The type of atomic TESL constraints, which can be combined to form specifications.
‚Ä∫
datatype 'œÑ TESL_atomic =
    SporadicOn       ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫ ‚Äπ'œÑ tag_const‚Ä∫  ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫  (‚Äπ_ sporadic _ on _‚Ä∫ 55)
  | TagRelation      ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫ ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫ ‚Äπ('œÑ tag_const √ó 'œÑ tag_const) ‚áí bool‚Ä∫ 
                                                      (‚Äπtime-relation ‚åä_, _‚åã ‚àà _‚Ä∫ 55)
  | Implies          ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫ ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫                  (infixr ‚Äπimplies‚Ä∫ 55)
  | ImpliesNot       ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫ ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫                  (infixr ‚Äπimplies not‚Ä∫ 55)
  | TimeDelayedBy    ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫ ‚Äπ'œÑ tag_const‚Ä∫ ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫ ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫ 
                                                      (‚Äπ_ time-delayed by _ on _ implies _‚Ä∫ 55)
  | WeaklyPrecedes   ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫ ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫                  (infixr ‚Äπweakly precedes‚Ä∫ 55)
  | StrictlyPrecedes ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫ ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫                  (infixr ‚Äπstrictly precedes‚Ä∫ 55)
  | Kills            ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫ ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫                  (infixr ‚Äπkills‚Ä∫ 55)

text‚Äπ
  A TESL formula is just a list of atomic constraints, with implicit conjunction
  for the semantics.
‚Ä∫
type_synonym 'œÑ TESL_formula = ‚Äπ'œÑ TESL_atomic list‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  We call ‚àó‚Äπpositive atoms‚Ä∫ the atomic constraints that create ticks from nothing.
  Only sporadic constraints are positive in the current version of TESL.
‚Ä∫
fun positive_atom :: ‚Äπ'œÑ TESL_atomic ‚áí bool‚Ä∫ where
    ‚Äπpositive_atom (_ sporadic _ on _) = True‚Ä∫
  | ‚Äπpositive_atom _                   = False‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  The @{term ‚ÄπNoSporadic‚Ä∫} function removes sporadic constraints from a TESL formula.
‚Ä∫
abbreviation NoSporadic :: ‚Äπ'œÑ TESL_formula ‚áí 'œÑ TESL_formula‚Ä∫
where 
  ‚ÄπNoSporadic f ‚â° (List.filter (Œªf‚á©a‚á©t‚á©o‚á©m. case f‚á©a‚á©t‚á©o‚á©m of
      _ sporadic _ on _ ‚áí False
    | _ ‚áí True) f)‚Ä∫

subsection‚ÄπField Structure of the Metric Time Space‚Ä∫
text‚Äπ
  In order to handle tag relations and delays, tags must belong to a field.
  We show here that this is the case when the type parameter of @{typ ‚Äπ'œÑ tag_const‚Ä∫} 
  is itself a field.
‚Ä∫
instantiation tag_const ::(field)field
begin
  fun inverse_tag_const
  where ‚Äπinverse (œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t t) = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t (inverse t)‚Ä∫

  fun divide_tag_const 
    where ‚Äπdivide (œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t t‚á©1) (œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t t‚á©2) = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t (divide t‚á©1 t‚á©2)‚Ä∫

  fun uminus_tag_const
    where ‚Äπuminus (œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t t) = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t (uminus t)‚Ä∫

fun minus_tag_const
  where ‚Äπminus (œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t t‚á©1) (œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t t‚á©2) = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t (minus t‚á©1 t‚á©2)‚Ä∫

definition ‚Äπone_tag_const ‚â° œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t 1‚Ä∫

fun times_tag_const
  where ‚Äπtimes (œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t t‚á©1) (œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t t‚á©2) = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t (times t‚á©1 t‚á©2)‚Ä∫

definition ‚Äπzero_tag_const ‚â° œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t 0‚Ä∫

fun plus_tag_const
  where ‚Äπplus (œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t t‚á©1) (œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t t‚á©2) = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t (plus t‚á©1 t‚á©2)‚Ä∫

instance proof
  text‚ÄπMultiplication is associative.‚Ä∫
  fix a::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫ and b::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫
                               and c::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫
  obtain u v w where ‚Äπa = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t u‚Ä∫ and ‚Äπb = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t v‚Ä∫ and ‚Äπc = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t w‚Ä∫
    using tag_const.exhaust by metis
  thus ‚Äπa * b * c = a * (b * c)‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: TESL.times_tag_const.simps)
next
  text‚ÄπMultiplication is commutative.‚Ä∫
  fix a::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫ and b::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫
  obtain u v where ‚Äπa = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t u‚Ä∫ and ‚Äπb = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t v‚Ä∫ using tag_const.exhaust by metis
  thus ‚Äπ a * b = b * a‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: TESL.times_tag_const.simps)
next
  text‚ÄπOne is neutral for multiplication.‚Ä∫
  fix a::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫
  obtain u where ‚Äπa = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t u‚Ä∫ using tag_const.exhaust by blast
  thus ‚Äπ1 * a = a‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: TESL.times_tag_const.simps one_tag_const_def)
next
  text‚ÄπAddition is associative.‚Ä∫
  fix a::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫ and b::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫
                               and c::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫
  obtain u v w where ‚Äπa = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t u‚Ä∫ and ‚Äπb = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t v‚Ä∫ and ‚Äπc = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t w‚Ä∫
    using tag_const.exhaust by metis
  thus ‚Äπa + b + c = a + (b + c)‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: TESL.plus_tag_const.simps)
next
  text‚ÄπAddition is commutative.‚Ä∫
  fix a::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫ and b::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫
  obtain u v where ‚Äπa = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t u‚Ä∫ and ‚Äπb = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t v‚Ä∫ using tag_const.exhaust by metis
  thus ‚Äπa + b = b + a‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: TESL.plus_tag_const.simps)
next
  text‚ÄπZero is neutral for addition.‚Ä∫
  fix a::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫
  obtain u where ‚Äπa = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t u‚Ä∫ using tag_const.exhaust by blast
  thus ‚Äπ0 + a = a‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: TESL.plus_tag_const.simps zero_tag_const_def)
next
  text‚ÄπThe sum of an element and its opposite is zero.‚Ä∫
  fix a::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫
  obtain u where ‚Äπa = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t u‚Ä∫ using tag_const.exhaust by blast
  thus ‚Äπ-a + a = 0‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: TESL.plus_tag_const.simps
                  TESL.uminus_tag_const.simps
                  zero_tag_const_def)
next
  text‚ÄπSubtraction is adding the opposite.‚Ä∫
  fix a::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫ and b::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫
  obtain u v where ‚Äπa = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t u‚Ä∫ and ‚Äπb = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t v‚Ä∫ using tag_const.exhaust by metis
  thus ‚Äπa - b = a + -b‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: TESL.minus_tag_const.simps
                  TESL.plus_tag_const.simps
                  TESL.uminus_tag_const.simps)
next
  text‚ÄπDistributive property of multiplication over addition.‚Ä∫
  fix a::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫ and b::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫
                               and c::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫
  obtain u v w where ‚Äπa = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t u‚Ä∫ and ‚Äπb = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t v‚Ä∫ and ‚Äπc = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t w‚Ä∫
    using tag_const.exhaust by metis
  thus ‚Äπ(a + b) * c = a * c + b * c‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: TESL.plus_tag_const.simps
                  TESL.times_tag_const.simps
                  ring_class.ring_distribs(2))
next
  text‚ÄπThe neutral elements are distinct.‚Ä∫
  show ‚Äπ(0::('œÑ::field tag_const)) ‚â† 1‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: one_tag_const_def zero_tag_const_def)
next
  text‚ÄπThe product of an element and its inverse is 1.‚Ä∫
  fix a::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫ assume h:‚Äπa ‚â† 0‚Ä∫
  obtain u where ‚Äπa = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t u‚Ä∫ using tag_const.exhaust by blast
  moreover with h have ‚Äπu ‚â† 0‚Ä∫ by (simp add: zero_tag_const_def)
  ultimately show ‚Äπinverse a * a = 1‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: TESL.inverse_tag_const.simps
                  TESL.times_tag_const.simps
                  one_tag_const_def)
next
  text‚ÄπDividing is multiplying by the inverse.‚Ä∫
  fix a::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫ and b::‚Äπ'œÑ::field tag_const‚Ä∫
  obtain u v where ‚Äπa = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t u‚Ä∫ and ‚Äπb = œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t v‚Ä∫ using tag_const.exhaust by metis
  thus ‚Äπa div b = a * inverse b‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: TESL.divide_tag_const.simps
                  TESL.inverse_tag_const.simps
                  TESL.times_tag_const.simps
                  divide_inverse)
next
  text‚ÄπZero is its own inverse.‚Ä∫
  show ‚Äπinverse (0::('œÑ::field tag_const)) = 0‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: TESL.inverse_tag_const.simps zero_tag_const_def)
qed

end

text‚Äπ
  For comparing dates (which are represented by tags) on clocks, we need an order on tags.
‚Ä∫

instantiation tag_const :: (order)order
begin
  inductive less_eq_tag_const :: ‚Äπ'a tag_const ‚áí 'a tag_const ‚áí bool‚Ä∫
  where
    Int_less_eq[simp]:      ‚Äπn ‚â§ m ‚üπ (TConst n) ‚â§ (TConst m)‚Ä∫

  definition less_tag: ‚Äπ(x::'a tag_const) < y ‚ü∑ (x ‚â§ y) ‚àß (x ‚â† y)‚Ä∫

  instance proof
    show ‚Äπ‚ãÄx y :: 'a tag_const. (x < y) = (x ‚â§ y ‚àß ¬¨ y ‚â§ x)‚Ä∫
      using less_eq_tag_const.simps less_tag by auto
  next
    fix x::‚Äπ'a tag_const‚Ä∫
    from tag_const.exhaust obtain x‚á©0::'a where ‚Äπx = TConst x‚á©0‚Ä∫ by blast
    with Int_less_eq show ‚Äπx ‚â§ x‚Ä∫ by simp
  next
    show ‚Äπ‚ãÄx y z  :: 'a tag_const. x ‚â§ y ‚üπ y ‚â§ z ‚üπ x ‚â§ z‚Ä∫
      using less_eq_tag_const.simps by auto
  next
    show ‚Äπ‚ãÄx y  :: 'a tag_const. x ‚â§ y ‚üπ y ‚â§ x ‚üπ x = y‚Ä∫
      using less_eq_tag_const.simps by auto
  qed

end

text‚Äπ
  For ensuring that time does never flow backwards, we need a total order on tags.
‚Ä∫
instantiation tag_const :: (linorder)linorder
begin
  instance proof
    fix x::‚Äπ'a tag_const‚Ä∫ and y::‚Äπ'a tag_const‚Ä∫
    from tag_const.exhaust obtain x‚á©0::'a where ‚Äπx = TConst x‚á©0‚Ä∫ by blast
    moreover from tag_const.exhaust obtain y‚á©0::'a where ‚Äπy = TConst y‚á©0‚Ä∫ by blast
    ultimately show ‚Äπx ‚â§ y ‚à® y ‚â§ x‚Ä∫ using less_eq_tag_const.simps by fastforce
  qed

end

end

Theory Run

section ‚Äπ Defining Runs ‚Ä∫

theory Run
imports TESL
      
begin
text ‚Äπ
  Runs are sequences of instants, and each instant maps a clock to a pair 
  @{term ‚Äπ(h, t)‚Ä∫} where @{term ‚Äπh‚Ä∫} indicates whether the clock ticks or not, 
  and @{term ‚Äπt‚Ä∫} is the current time on this clock.
  The first element of the pair is called the ‚àó‚Äπhamlet‚Ä∫ of the clock (to tick or 
  not to tick), the second element is called the ‚àó‚Äπtime‚Ä∫.
‚Ä∫

abbreviation hamlet where ‚Äπhamlet ‚â° fst‚Ä∫
abbreviation time   where ‚Äπtime ‚â° snd‚Ä∫

type_synonym 'œÑ instant = ‚Äπclock ‚áí (bool √ó 'œÑ tag_const)‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  Runs have the additional constraint that time cannot go backwards on any clock
  in the sequence of instants.
  Therefore, for any clock, the time projection of a run is monotonous.
‚Ä∫
typedef (overloaded) 'œÑ::linordered_field run =
  ‚Äπ{ œÅ::nat ‚áí 'œÑ instant. ‚àÄc. mono (Œªn. time (œÅ n c)) }‚Ä∫
proof
  show ‚Äπ(Œª_ _. (True, œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t 0)) ‚àà {œÅ. ‚àÄc. mono (Œªn. time (œÅ n c))}‚Ä∫ 
    unfolding mono_def by blast
qed

lemma Abs_run_inverse_rewrite:
  ‚Äπ‚àÄc. mono (Œªn. time (œÅ n c)) ‚üπ Rep_run (Abs_run œÅ) = œÅ‚Ä∫
by (simp add: Abs_run_inverse)

text ‚Äπ
  A ‚àó‚Äπdense‚Ä∫ run is a run in which something happens (at least one clock ticks) 
  at every instant.
‚Ä∫
definition ‚Äπdense_run œÅ ‚â° (‚àÄn. ‚àÉc. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n c))‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  @{term ‚Äπrun_tick_count œÅ K n‚Ä∫} counts the number of ticks on clock @{term ‚ÄπK‚Ä∫} 
  in the interval ‚ñ©‚Äπ[0, n]‚Ä∫ of run @{term ‚ÄπœÅ‚Ä∫}.
‚Ä∫
fun run_tick_count :: ‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) run ‚áí clock ‚áí nat ‚áí nat‚Ä∫
  (‚Äπ#‚á©‚â§ _ _ _‚Ä∫)
where
  ‚Äπ(#‚á©‚â§ œÅ K 0)       = (if hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) 0 K)
                       then 1
                       else 0)‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ(#‚á©‚â§ œÅ K (Suc n)) = (if hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) (Suc n) K)
                       then 1 + (#‚á©‚â§ œÅ K n)
                       else (#‚á©‚â§ œÅ K n))‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  @{term ‚Äπrun_tick_count_strictly œÅ K n‚Ä∫} counts the number of ticks on
  clock @{term ‚ÄπK‚Ä∫} in the interval ‚ñ©‚Äπ[0, n[‚Ä∫ of run @{term ‚ÄπœÅ‚Ä∫}.
‚Ä∫
fun run_tick_count_strictly :: ‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) run ‚áí clock ‚áí nat ‚áí nat‚Ä∫
  (‚Äπ#‚á©< _ _ _‚Ä∫)
where
  ‚Äπ(#‚á©< œÅ K 0)       = 0‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ(#‚á©< œÅ K (Suc n)) = #‚á©‚â§ œÅ K n‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  @{term ‚Äπfirst_time œÅ K n œÑ‚Ä∫} tells whether instant @{term ‚Äπn‚Ä∫} in run @{term‚ÄπœÅ‚Ä∫}
  is the first one where the time on clock @{term ‚ÄπK‚Ä∫} reaches @{term ‚ÄπœÑ‚Ä∫}.
‚Ä∫
definition first_time :: ‚Äπ'a::linordered_field run ‚áí clock ‚áí nat ‚áí 'a tag_const
                          ‚áí bool‚Ä∫
where
  ‚Äπfirst_time œÅ K n œÑ ‚â° (time ((Rep_run œÅ) n K) = œÑ)
                      ‚àß (‚àÑn'. n' < n ‚àß time ((Rep_run œÅ) n' K) = œÑ)‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  The time on a clock is necessarily less than @{term ‚ÄπœÑ‚Ä∫} before the first instant
  at which it reaches @{term ‚ÄπœÑ‚Ä∫}.
‚Ä∫
lemma before_first_time:
  assumes ‚Äπfirst_time œÅ K n œÑ‚Ä∫
      and ‚Äπm < n‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπtime ((Rep_run œÅ) m K) < œÑ‚Ä∫
proof -
  have ‚Äπmono (Œªn. time (Rep_run œÅ n K))‚Ä∫ using Rep_run by blast
  moreover from assms(2) have ‚Äπm ‚â§ n‚Ä∫ using less_imp_le by simp
  moreover have ‚Äπmono (Œªn. time (Rep_run œÅ n K))‚Ä∫ using Rep_run by blast
  ultimately have  ‚Äπtime ((Rep_run œÅ) m K) ‚â§ time ((Rep_run œÅ) n K)‚Ä∫
    by (simp add:mono_def)
  moreover from assms(1) have ‚Äπtime ((Rep_run œÅ) n K) = œÑ‚Ä∫
    using first_time_def by blast
  moreover from assms have ‚Äπtime ((Rep_run œÅ) m K) ‚â† œÑ‚Ä∫
    using first_time_def by blast
  ultimately show ?thesis by simp
qed

text‚Äπ
  This leads to an alternate definition of @{term ‚Äπfirst_time‚Ä∫}:
‚Ä∫
lemma alt_first_time_def:
  assumes ‚Äπ‚àÄm < n. time ((Rep_run œÅ) m K) < œÑ‚Ä∫
      and ‚Äπtime ((Rep_run œÅ) n K) = œÑ‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπfirst_time œÅ K n œÑ‚Ä∫
proof -
  from assms(1) have ‚Äπ‚àÄm < n. time ((Rep_run œÅ) m K) ‚â† œÑ‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: less_le)
  with assms(2) show ?thesis by (simp add: first_time_def)
qed

end

Theory Denotational

chapter ‚ÄπDenotational Semantics‚Ä∫

theory Denotational
imports
    TESL
    Run

begin
text‚Äπ
  The denotational semantics maps TESL formulae to sets of satisfying runs.
  Firstly, we define the semantics of atomic formulae (basic constructs of the 
  TESL language), then we define the semantics of compound formulae as the
  intersection of the semantics of their components: a run must satisfy all
  the individual formulae of a compound formula.
‚Ä∫
section ‚ÄπDenotational interpretation for atomic TESL formulae‚Ä∫
(*<*)
consts dummyT0 ::‚Äπ'œÑ tag_const‚Ä∫
consts dummyDeltaT ::‚Äπ'œÑ tag_const‚Ä∫

notation dummyT0     (‚Äπt‚á©0‚Ä∫)
notation dummyDeltaT (‚ÄπŒ¥t‚Ä∫)
(*>*)

fun TESL_interpretation_atomic
    :: ‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) TESL_atomic ‚áí 'œÑ run set‚Ä∫ (‚Äπ‚ü¶ _ ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫)
where
  ‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚ÄπK‚á©1 sporadic œÑ on K‚á©2‚Ä∫} means that @{term ‚ÄπK‚á©1‚Ä∫} should tick at an 
      instant where the time on @{term ‚ÄπK‚á©2‚Ä∫} is @{term ‚ÄπœÑ‚Ä∫}.‚Ä∫
    ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 sporadic œÑ on K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L =
        {œÅ. ‚àÉn::nat. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n K‚á©1) ‚àß time ((Rep_run œÅ) n K‚á©2) = œÑ}‚Ä∫
  ‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚Äπtime-relation ‚åäK‚á©1, K‚á©2‚åã ‚àà R‚Ä∫} means that at each instant, the time 
      on @{term ‚ÄπK‚á©1‚Ä∫} and the time on @{term ‚ÄπK‚á©2‚Ä∫} are in relation~@{term ‚ÄπR‚Ä∫}.‚Ä∫
  | ‚Äπ‚ü¶ time-relation ‚åäK‚á©1, K‚á©2‚åã ‚àà R ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L =
        {œÅ. ‚àÄn::nat. R (time ((Rep_run œÅ) n K‚á©1), time ((Rep_run œÅ) n K‚á©2))}‚Ä∫
  ‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚Äπmaster implies slave‚Ä∫} means that at each instant at which 
      @{term ‚Äπmaster‚Ä∫} ticks, @{term ‚Äπslave‚Ä∫} also ticks.‚Ä∫
  | ‚Äπ‚ü¶ master implies slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L =
        {œÅ. ‚àÄn::nat. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n master) ‚ü∂ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n slave)}‚Ä∫
  ‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚Äπmaster implies not slave‚Ä∫} means that at each instant at which 
      @{term ‚Äπmaster‚Ä∫} ticks, @{term ‚Äπslave‚Ä∫} does not tick.‚Ä∫
  | ‚Äπ‚ü¶ master implies not slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L =
        {œÅ. ‚àÄn::nat. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n master) ‚ü∂ ¬¨hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n slave)}‚Ä∫
  ‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚Äπmaster time-delayed by Œ¥œÑ on measuring implies slave‚Ä∫} means that 
      at each instant at which  @{term ‚Äπmaster‚Ä∫} ticks, @{term ‚Äπslave‚Ä∫} will
      tick after a delay @{term ‚ÄπŒ¥œÑ‚Ä∫} measured on the time scale 
      of @{term ‚Äπmeasuring‚Ä∫}.‚Ä∫
  | ‚Äπ‚ü¶ master time-delayed by Œ¥œÑ on measuring implies slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L =
    ‚Äï ‚Äπ
      When master ticks, let's call @{term ‚Äπt‚á©0‚Ä∫} the current date on measuring. Then, 
      at the first instant when the date on measuring is @{term ‚Äπt‚á©0+Œ¥t‚Ä∫}, 
      slave has to tick.
    ‚Ä∫
        {œÅ. ‚àÄn. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n master) ‚ü∂
                 (let measured_time = time ((Rep_run œÅ) n measuring) in
                  ‚àÄm ‚â• n.  first_time œÅ measuring m (measured_time + Œ¥œÑ)
                            ‚ü∂ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) m slave)
                 )
        }‚Ä∫
  ‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚ÄπK‚á©1 weakly precedes K‚á©2‚Ä∫} means that each tick on @{term ‚ÄπK‚á©2‚Ä∫}
        must be preceded by or coincide with at least one tick on @{term ‚ÄπK‚á©1‚Ä∫}.
        Therefore, at each instant @{term ‚Äπn‚Ä∫}, the number of ticks on @{term ‚ÄπK‚á©2‚Ä∫} 
        must be less or equal to the number of ticks on @{term ‚ÄπK‚á©1‚Ä∫}.‚Ä∫
  | ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 weakly precedes K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L =
        {œÅ. ‚àÄn::nat. (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©2 n) ‚â§ (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©1 n)}‚Ä∫
  ‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚ÄπK‚á©1 strictly precedes K‚á©2‚Ä∫} means that each tick on @{term ‚ÄπK‚á©2‚Ä∫}
        must be preceded by at least one tick on @{term ‚ÄπK‚á©1‚Ä∫} at a previous instant.
        Therefore, at each instant n, the number of ticks on @{term ‚ÄπK‚á©2‚Ä∫}
        must be less or equal to the number of ticks on @{term ‚ÄπK‚á©1‚Ä∫} 
        at instant n - 1.‚Ä∫
  | ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 strictly precedes K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L =
        {œÅ. ‚àÄn::nat. (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©2 n) ‚â§ (run_tick_count_strictly œÅ K‚á©1 n)}‚Ä∫
  ‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚ÄπK‚á©1 kills K‚á©2‚Ä∫} means that when @{term ‚ÄπK‚á©1‚Ä∫} ticks, @{term ‚ÄπK‚á©2‚Ä∫}
        cannot tick and is not allowed to tick at any further instant.‚Ä∫
  | ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 kills K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L =
        {œÅ. ‚àÄn::nat. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n K‚á©1)
                        ‚ü∂ (‚àÄm‚â•n. ¬¨ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) m K‚á©2))}‚Ä∫

section ‚ÄπDenotational interpretation for TESL formulae‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  To satisfy a formula, a run has to satisfy the conjunction of its atomic 
  formulae. Therefore, the interpretation of a formula is the intersection
  of the interpretations of its components.
‚Ä∫
fun TESL_interpretation :: ‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) TESL_formula ‚áí 'œÑ run set‚Ä∫
  (‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ _ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫)
where
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ [] ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = {_. True}‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ œÜ # Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶ œÜ ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L ‚à© ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫

lemma TESL_interpretation_homo:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ œÜ ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L ‚à© ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ œÜ # Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
by simp

subsection ‚ÄπImage interpretation lemma‚Ä∫

theorem TESL_interpretation_image:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ãÇ ((ŒªœÜ. ‚ü¶ œÜ ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L) ` set Œ¶)‚Ä∫
by (induction Œ¶, simp+)

subsection ‚ÄπExpansion law‚Ä∫
text ‚ÄπSimilar to the expansion laws of lattices.‚Ä∫

theorem TESL_interp_homo_append:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©1 @ Œ¶‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©1 ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L ‚à© ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
by (induction Œ¶‚á©1, simp, auto)

section ‚ÄπEquational laws for the denotation of TESL formulae‚Ä∫

lemma TESL_interp_assoc:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ (Œ¶‚á©1 @ Œ¶‚á©2) @ Œ¶‚á©3 ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©1 @ (Œ¶‚á©2 @ Œ¶‚á©3) ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
by auto

lemma TESL_interp_commute:
  shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©1 @ Œ¶‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©2 @ Œ¶‚á©1 ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
by (simp add: TESL_interp_homo_append inf_sup_aci(1))

lemma TESL_interp_left_commute:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©1 @ (Œ¶‚á©2 @ Œ¶‚á©3) ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©2 @ (Œ¶‚á©1 @ Œ¶‚á©3) ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
unfolding TESL_interp_homo_append by auto

lemma TESL_interp_idem:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ @ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
using TESL_interp_homo_append by auto

lemma TESL_interp_left_idem:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©1 @ (Œ¶‚á©1 @ Œ¶‚á©2) ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©1 @ Œ¶‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
using TESL_interp_homo_append by auto

lemma TESL_interp_right_idem:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ (Œ¶‚á©1 @ Œ¶‚á©2) @ Œ¶‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©1 @ Œ¶‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
unfolding TESL_interp_homo_append by auto

lemmas TESL_interp_aci = TESL_interp_commute
                         TESL_interp_assoc
                         TESL_interp_left_commute
                         TESL_interp_left_idem

text ‚ÄπThe empty formula is the identity element.‚Ä∫
lemma TESL_interp_neutral1:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ [] @ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
by simp

lemma TESL_interp_neutral2:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ @ [] ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
by simp

section ‚ÄπDecreasing interpretation of TESL formulae‚Ä∫
text‚Äπ
  Adding constraints to a TESL formula reduces the number of satisfying runs.
‚Ä∫
lemma TESL_sem_decreases_head:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L ‚äá ‚ü¶‚ü¶ œÜ # Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
by simp

lemma TESL_sem_decreases_tail:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L ‚äá ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ @ [œÜ] ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
by (simp add: TESL_interp_homo_append)

text ‚Äπ
  Repeating a formula in a specification does not change the specification.
‚Ä∫
lemma TESL_interp_formula_stuttering:
  assumes ‚ÄπœÜ ‚àà set Œ¶‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ œÜ # Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
proof -
  have ‚ÄπœÜ # Œ¶ = [œÜ] @ Œ¶‚Ä∫ by simp
  hence ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ œÜ # Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ [œÜ] ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L ‚à© ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
    using TESL_interp_homo_append by simp
  thus ?thesis using assms TESL_interpretation_image by fastforce
qed

text ‚Äπ
  Removing duplicate formulae in a specification does not change the specification.
‚Ä∫
lemma TESL_interp_remdups_absorb:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ remdups Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
proof (induction Œ¶)
  case Cons
    thus ?case using TESL_interp_formula_stuttering by auto
qed simp

text ‚Äπ
  Specifications that contain the same formulae have the same semantics.
‚Ä∫
lemma TESL_interp_set_lifting:
  assumes ‚Äπset Œ¶ = set Œ¶'‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶' ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
proof -     
  have ‚Äπset (remdups Œ¶) = set (remdups Œ¶')‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: assms)
  moreover have fxpntŒ¶: ‚Äπ‚ãÇ ((ŒªœÜ. ‚ü¶ œÜ ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L) ` set Œ¶) = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: TESL_interpretation_image)
  moreover have fxpntŒ¶': ‚Äπ‚ãÇ ((ŒªœÜ. ‚ü¶ œÜ ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L) ` set Œ¶') = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶' ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: TESL_interpretation_image)
  moreover have ‚Äπ‚ãÇ ((ŒªœÜ. ‚ü¶ œÜ ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L) ` set Œ¶) = ‚ãÇ ((ŒªœÜ. ‚ü¶ œÜ ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L) ` set Œ¶')‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: assms)
  ultimately show ?thesis using TESL_interp_remdups_absorb by auto
qed

text ‚Äπ
  The semantics of specifications is contravariant with respect to their inclusion.
‚Ä∫
theorem TESL_interp_decreases_setinc:
  assumes ‚Äπset Œ¶ ‚äÜ set Œ¶'‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L ‚äá ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶' ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
proof -
  obtain Œ¶‚á©r where decompose: ‚Äπset (Œ¶ @ Œ¶‚á©r) = set Œ¶'‚Ä∫ using assms by auto
  hence ‚Äπset (Œ¶ @ Œ¶‚á©r) = set Œ¶'‚Ä∫ using assms by blast
  moreover have ‚Äπ(set Œ¶) ‚à™ (set Œ¶‚á©r) = set Œ¶'‚Ä∫
    using assms decompose by auto
  moreover have ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶' ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ @ Œ¶‚á©r ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
    using TESL_interp_set_lifting decompose by blast
  moreover have ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ @ Œ¶‚á©r ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L ‚à© ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©r ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: TESL_interp_homo_append)
  moreover have ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L ‚äá ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L ‚à© ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©r ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫ by simp
  ultimately show ?thesis by simp
qed

lemma TESL_interp_decreases_add_head:
  assumes ‚Äπset Œ¶ ‚äÜ set Œ¶'‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ œÜ # Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L ‚äá ‚ü¶‚ü¶ œÜ # Œ¶' ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
using assms TESL_interp_decreases_setinc by auto

lemma TESL_interp_decreases_add_tail:
  assumes ‚Äπset Œ¶ ‚äÜ set Œ¶'‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ @ [œÜ] ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L ‚äá ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶' @ [œÜ] ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
using TESL_interp_decreases_setinc[OF assms] 
  by (simp add: TESL_interpretation_image dual_order.trans)

lemma TESL_interp_absorb1:
  assumes ‚Äπset Œ¶‚á©1 ‚äÜ set Œ¶‚á©2‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©1 @ Œ¶‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
by (simp add: Int_absorb1 TESL_interp_decreases_setinc
                          TESL_interp_homo_append assms)

lemma TESL_interp_absorb2:
  assumes ‚Äπset Œ¶‚á©2 ‚äÜ set Œ¶‚á©1‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©1 @ Œ¶‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶‚á©1 ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
using TESL_interp_absorb1 TESL_interp_commute assms by blast

section ‚ÄπSome special cases‚Ä∫

lemma NoSporadic_stable [simp]:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L ‚äÜ ‚ü¶‚ü¶ NoSporadic Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
proof -
  from filter_is_subset have ‚Äπset (NoSporadic Œ¶) ‚äÜ set Œ¶‚Ä∫ .
  from TESL_interp_decreases_setinc[OF this] show ?thesis .
qed

lemma NoSporadic_idem [simp]:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L ‚à© ‚ü¶‚ü¶ NoSporadic Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ¶ ‚üß‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚Ä∫
using NoSporadic_stable by blast

lemma NoSporadic_setinc:
  ‚Äπset (NoSporadic Œ¶) ‚äÜ set Œ¶‚Ä∫
by (rule filter_is_subset)

(*<*)
no_notation dummyT0    (‚Äπt‚á©0‚Ä∫)
no_notation dummyDeltaT (‚ÄπŒ¥t‚Ä∫)
(*>*)

end

Theory SymbolicPrimitive

chapter ‚ÄπSymbolic Primitives for Building Runs‚Ä∫

theory SymbolicPrimitive
  imports Run

begin

text‚Äπ
  We define here the primitive constraints on runs, towards which we translate
  TESL specifications in the operational semantics.
  These constraints refer to a specific symbolic run and can therefore access
  properties of the run at particular instants (for instance, the fact that a clock
  ticks at instant @{term ‚Äπn‚Ä∫} of the run, or the time on a given clock at 
  that instant).

  In the previous chapters, we had no reference to particular instants of a run 
  because the TESL language should be invariant by stuttering in order to allow 
  the composition of specifications: adding an instant where no clock ticks to 
  a run that satisfies a formula should yield another run that satisfies the 
  same formula. However, when constructing runs that satisfy a formula, we
  need to be able to refer to the time or hamlet of a clock at a given instant.
‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  Counter expressions are used to get the number of ticks of a clock up to 
  (strictly or not) a given instant index.
‚Ä∫
datatype cnt_expr =
  TickCountLess ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫ ‚Äπinstant_index‚Ä∫ (‚Äπ#‚áß<‚Ä∫)
| TickCountLeq ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫ ‚Äπinstant_index‚Ä∫  (‚Äπ#‚áß‚â§‚Ä∫)

subsection‚Äπ Symbolic Primitives for Runs ‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  Tag values are used to refer to the time on a clock at a given instant index.
‚Ä∫
datatype tag_val =
  TSchematic ‚Äπclock * instant_index‚Ä∫ (‚ÄπœÑ‚á©v‚á©a‚á©r‚Ä∫)

datatype 'œÑ constr =
‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚Äπc ‚áì n @ œÑ‚Ä∫} constrains clock @{term ‚Äπc‚Ä∫} to have time @{term ‚ÄπœÑ‚Ä∫}
    at instant @{term ‚Äπn‚Ä∫} of the run.‚Ä∫
  Timestamp     ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫   ‚Äπinstant_index‚Ä∫ ‚Äπ'œÑ tag_const‚Ä∫         (‚Äπ_ ‚áì _ @ _‚Ä∫)
‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚Äπm @ n ‚äï Œ¥t ‚áí s‚Ä∫} constrains clock @{term ‚Äπs‚Ä∫} to tick at the
    first instant at which the time on @{term ‚Äπm‚Ä∫} has increased by @{term ‚ÄπŒ¥t‚Ä∫}
    from the value it had at instant @{term ‚Äπn‚Ä∫} of the run.‚Ä∫
| TimeDelay     ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫   ‚Äπinstant_index‚Ä∫ ‚Äπ'œÑ tag_const‚Ä∫ ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫ (‚Äπ_ @ _ ‚äï _ ‚áí _‚Ä∫)
‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚Äπc ‚áë n‚Ä∫} constrains clock @{term ‚Äπc‚Ä∫} to tick
    at instant @{term ‚Äπn‚Ä∫} of the run.‚Ä∫
| Ticks         ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫   ‚Äπinstant_index‚Ä∫                        (‚Äπ_ ‚áë _‚Ä∫)
‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚Äπc ¬¨‚áë n‚Ä∫} constrains clock @{term ‚Äπc‚Ä∫} not to tick
    at instant @{term ‚Äπn‚Ä∫} of the run.‚Ä∫
| NotTicks      ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫   ‚Äπinstant_index‚Ä∫                        (‚Äπ_ ¬¨‚áë _‚Ä∫)
‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚Äπc ¬¨‚áë < n‚Ä∫} constrains clock @{term ‚Äπc‚Ä∫} not to tick
    before instant @{term ‚Äπn‚Ä∫} of the run.‚Ä∫
| NotTicksUntil ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫   ‚Äπinstant_index‚Ä∫                        (‚Äπ_ ¬¨‚áë < _‚Ä∫)
‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚Äπc ¬¨‚áë ‚â• n‚Ä∫} constrains clock @{term ‚Äπc‚Ä∫} not to tick
    at and after instant @{term ‚Äπn‚Ä∫} of the run.‚Ä∫
| NotTicksFrom  ‚Äπclock‚Ä∫   ‚Äπinstant_index‚Ä∫                        (‚Äπ_ ¬¨‚áë ‚â• _‚Ä∫)
‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚Äπ‚åäœÑ‚á©1, œÑ‚á©2‚åã ‚àà R‚Ä∫} constrains tag variables @{term ‚ÄπœÑ‚á©1‚Ä∫} and  @{term ‚ÄπœÑ‚á©2‚Ä∫} 
    to be in relation @{term ‚ÄπR‚Ä∫}.‚Ä∫
| TagArith      ‚Äπtag_val‚Ä∫ ‚Äπtag_val‚Ä∫ ‚Äπ('œÑ tag_const √ó 'œÑ tag_const) ‚áí bool‚Ä∫ (‚Äπ‚åä_, _‚åã ‚àà _‚Ä∫)
‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚Äπ‚åàk‚á©1, k‚á©2‚åâ ‚àà R‚Ä∫} constrains counter expressions @{term ‚Äπk‚á©1‚Ä∫} and  @{term ‚Äπk‚á©2‚Ä∫} 
    to be in relation @{term ‚ÄπR‚Ä∫}.‚Ä∫
| TickCntArith  ‚Äπcnt_expr‚Ä∫ ‚Äπcnt_expr‚Ä∫ ‚Äπ(nat √ó nat) ‚áí bool‚Ä∫      (‚Äπ‚åà_, _‚åâ ‚àà _‚Ä∫)
‚Äï ‚Äπ@{term ‚Äπk‚á©1 ‚âº k‚á©2‚Ä∫} constrains counter expression @{term ‚Äπk‚á©1‚Ä∫} to be less or equal 
    to counter expression @{term ‚Äπk‚á©2‚Ä∫}.‚Ä∫
| TickCntLeq    ‚Äπcnt_expr‚Ä∫ ‚Äπcnt_expr‚Ä∫                            (‚Äπ_ ‚âº _‚Ä∫)

type_synonym 'œÑ system = ‚Äπ'œÑ constr list‚Ä∫


text ‚Äπ
  The abstract machine has configurations composed of:
  ‚ñ™ the past @{term‚ÄπŒì‚Ä∫}, which captures choices that have already be made as a 
    list of symbolic primitive constraints on the run;
  ‚ñ™ the current index @{term ‚Äπn‚Ä∫}, which is the index of the present instant;
  ‚ñ™ the present @{term‚ÄπŒ®‚Ä∫}, which captures the formulae that must be satisfied
    in the current instant;
  ‚ñ™ the future @{term‚ÄπŒ¶‚Ä∫}, which captures the constraints on the future of the run.
‚Ä∫
type_synonym 'œÑ config =
                ‚Äπ'œÑ system * instant_index * 'œÑ TESL_formula * 'œÑ TESL_formula‚Ä∫


section ‚ÄπSemantics of Primitive Constraints ‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  The semantics of the primitive constraints is defined in a way similar to
  the semantics of TESL formulae.
‚Ä∫
fun counter_expr_eval :: ‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) run ‚áí cnt_expr ‚áí nat‚Ä∫
  (‚Äπ‚ü¶ _ ‚ä¢ _ ‚üß‚á©c‚á©n‚á©t‚á©e‚á©x‚á©p‚á©r‚Ä∫)
where
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ œÅ ‚ä¢ #‚áß< clk indx ‚üß‚á©c‚á©n‚á©t‚á©e‚á©x‚á©p‚á©r = run_tick_count_strictly œÅ clk indx‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ œÅ ‚ä¢ #‚áß‚â§ clk indx ‚üß‚á©c‚á©n‚á©t‚á©e‚á©x‚á©p‚á©r = run_tick_count œÅ clk indx‚Ä∫


fun symbolic_run_interpretation_primitive
  ::‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) constr ‚áí 'œÑ run set‚Ä∫ (‚Äπ‚ü¶ _ ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫)
where
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K ‚áë n  ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m     = {œÅ. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n K) }‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K @ n‚á©0 ‚äï Œ¥t ‚áí K' ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m =
                  {œÅ. ‚àÄn ‚â• n‚á©0. first_time œÅ K n (time ((Rep_run œÅ) n‚á©0 K) + Œ¥t)
                               ‚ü∂ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n K')}‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K ¬¨‚áë n ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m     = {œÅ. ¬¨hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n K) }‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K ¬¨‚áë < n ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m   = {œÅ. ‚àÄi < n. ¬¨ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) i K)}‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K ¬¨‚áë ‚â• n ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m   = {œÅ. ‚àÄi ‚â• n. ¬¨ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) i K) }‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K ‚áì n @ œÑ ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = {œÅ. time ((Rep_run œÅ) n K) = œÑ }‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ ‚åäœÑ‚á©v‚á©a‚á©r(K‚á©1, n‚á©1), œÑ‚á©v‚á©a‚á©r(K‚á©2, n‚á©2)‚åã ‚àà R ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m =
    { œÅ. R (time ((Rep_run œÅ) n‚á©1 K‚á©1), time ((Rep_run œÅ) n‚á©2 K‚á©2)) }‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ ‚åàe‚á©1, e‚á©2‚åâ ‚àà R ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = { œÅ. R (‚ü¶ œÅ ‚ä¢ e‚á©1 ‚üß‚á©c‚á©n‚á©t‚á©e‚á©x‚á©p‚á©r, ‚ü¶ œÅ ‚ä¢ e‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©c‚á©n‚á©t‚á©e‚á©x‚á©p‚á©r) }‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ cnt_e‚á©1 ‚âº cnt_e‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = { œÅ. ‚ü¶ œÅ ‚ä¢ cnt_e‚á©1 ‚üß‚á©c‚á©n‚á©t‚á©e‚á©x‚á©p‚á©r ‚â§ ‚ü¶ œÅ ‚ä¢ cnt_e‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©c‚á©n‚á©t‚á©e‚á©x‚á©p‚á©r }‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  The composition of primitive constraints is their conjunction, and we get the
  set of satisfying runs by intersection.
‚Ä∫
fun symbolic_run_interpretation
  ::‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) constr list ‚áí ('œÑ::linordered_field) run set‚Ä∫
  (‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ _ ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫)
where
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ [] ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = {œÅ. True }‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ≥ # Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶ Œ≥ ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚à© ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫

lemma symbolic_run_interp_cons_morph:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ Œ≥ ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚à© ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ≥ # Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
by auto

definition consistent_context :: ‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) constr list ‚áí bool‚Ä∫
where 
  ‚Äπconsistent_context Œì ‚â° ( ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚â† {}) ‚Ä∫

subsection ‚ÄπDefining a method for witness construction‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  In order to build a run, we can start from an initial run in which no clock 
  ticks and the time is always 0 on any clock.
‚Ä∫
abbreviation initial_run :: ‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) run‚Ä∫ (‚ÄπœÅ‚á©‚äô‚Ä∫) where
  ‚ÄπœÅ‚á©‚äô ‚â° Abs_run ((Œª_ _. (False, œÑ‚á©c‚á©s‚á©t 0)) ::nat ‚áí clock ‚áí (bool √ó 'œÑ tag_const))‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  To help avoiding that time flows backward, setting the time on a clock at a given 
  instant sets it for the future instants too.
‚Ä∫
fun time_update
  :: ‚Äπnat ‚áí clock ‚áí ('œÑ::linordered_field) tag_const ‚áí (nat ‚áí 'œÑ instant)
      ‚áí (nat ‚áí 'œÑ instant)‚Ä∫
where
  ‚Äπtime_update n K œÑ œÅ = (Œªn' K'. if K = K' ‚àß n ‚â§ n'
                                  then (hamlet (œÅ n K), œÑ)
                                  else œÅ n' K')‚Ä∫


section ‚ÄπRules and properties of consistence‚Ä∫

lemma context_consistency_preservationI:
  ‚Äπconsistent_context ((Œ≥::('œÑ::linordered_field) constr)#Œì) ‚üπ consistent_context Œì‚Ä∫
unfolding consistent_context_def by auto

‚Äï ‚ÄπThis is very restrictive‚Ä∫
inductive context_independency
  ::‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) constr ‚áí 'œÑ constr list ‚áí bool‚Ä∫ (‚Äπ_ ‚®ù _‚Ä∫)
where
  NotTicks_independency:
  ‚Äπ(K ‚áë n) ‚àâ set Œì ‚üπ (K ¬¨‚áë n) ‚®ù Œì‚Ä∫
| Ticks_independency:
  ‚Äπ(K ¬¨‚áë n) ‚àâ set Œì ‚üπ (K ‚áë n) ‚®ù Œì‚Ä∫
| Timestamp_independency:
  ‚Äπ(‚àÑœÑ'. œÑ' = œÑ ‚àß (K ‚áì n @ œÑ) ‚àà set Œì) ‚üπ (K ‚áì n @ œÑ) ‚®ù Œì‚Ä∫


section‚ÄπMajor Theorems‚Ä∫
subsection ‚ÄπInterpretation of a context‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  The interpretation of a context is the intersection of the interpretation 
  of its components.
‚Ä∫
theorem symrun_interp_fixpoint:
  ‚Äπ‚ãÇ ((ŒªŒ≥. ‚ü¶ Œ≥ ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m) ` set Œì) = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
by (induction Œì, simp+)

subsection ‚ÄπExpansion law‚Ä∫
text ‚ÄπSimilar to the expansion laws of lattices‚Ä∫

theorem symrun_interp_expansion:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©1 @ Œì‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©1 ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚à© ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
by (induction Œì‚á©1, simp, auto)

section ‚ÄπEquations for the interpretation of symbolic primitives‚Ä∫ 
subsection ‚ÄπGeneral laws‚Ä∫

lemma symrun_interp_assoc:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ (Œì‚á©1 @ Œì‚á©2) @ Œì‚á©3 ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©1 @ (Œì‚á©2 @ Œì‚á©3) ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
by auto

lemma symrun_interp_commute:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©1 @ Œì‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©2 @ Œì‚á©1 ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
by (simp add: symrun_interp_expansion inf_sup_aci(1))

lemma symrun_interp_left_commute:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©1 @ (Œì‚á©2 @ Œì‚á©3) ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©2 @ (Œì‚á©1 @ Œì‚á©3) ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
unfolding symrun_interp_expansion by auto

lemma symrun_interp_idem:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì @ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
using symrun_interp_expansion by auto

lemma symrun_interp_left_idem:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©1 @ (Œì‚á©1 @ Œì‚á©2) ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©1 @ Œì‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
using symrun_interp_expansion by auto

lemma symrun_interp_right_idem:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ (Œì‚á©1 @ Œì‚á©2) @ Œì‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©1 @ Œì‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
unfolding symrun_interp_expansion by auto

lemmas symrun_interp_aci =  symrun_interp_commute
                            symrun_interp_assoc
                            symrun_interp_left_commute
                            symrun_interp_left_idem

‚Äï ‚ÄπIdentity element‚Ä∫
lemma symrun_interp_neutral1:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ [] @ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
by simp

lemma symrun_interp_neutral2:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì @ [] ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
by simp

subsection ‚ÄπDecreasing interpretation of symbolic primitives‚Ä∫

text‚Äπ
  Adding constraints to a context reduces the number of satisfying runs.
‚Ä∫
lemma TESL_sem_decreases_head:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚äá ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ≥ # Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
by simp

lemma TESL_sem_decreases_tail:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚äá ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì @ [Œ≥] ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
by (simp add: symrun_interp_expansion)

text‚Äπ
  Adding a constraint that is already in the context does not change the
  interpretation of the context.
‚Ä∫
lemma symrun_interp_formula_stuttering:
  assumes ‚ÄπŒ≥ ‚àà set Œì‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ≥ # Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
proof -
  have ‚ÄπŒ≥ # Œì = [Œ≥] @ Œì‚Ä∫ by simp
  hence ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ≥ # Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ [Œ≥] ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚à© ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
    using symrun_interp_expansion by simp
  thus ?thesis using assms symrun_interp_fixpoint by fastforce
qed


text‚Äπ
  Removing duplicate constraints from a context does not change the
  interpretation of the context.
‚Ä∫
lemma symrun_interp_remdups_absorb:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ remdups Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
proof (induction Œì)
  case Cons
    thus ?case using symrun_interp_formula_stuttering by auto
qed simp

text‚Äπ
  Two identical sets of constraints have the same interpretation,
  the order in the context does not matter.
‚Ä∫
lemma symrun_interp_set_lifting:
  assumes ‚Äπset Œì = set Œì'‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì' ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
proof -     
  have ‚Äπset (remdups Œì) = set (remdups Œì')‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: assms)
  moreover have fxpntŒì: ‚Äπ‚ãÇ ((ŒªŒ≥. ‚ü¶ Œ≥ ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m) ` set Œì) = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: symrun_interp_fixpoint)
  moreover have fxpntŒì': ‚Äπ‚ãÇ ((ŒªŒ≥. ‚ü¶ Œ≥ ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m) ` set Œì') = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì' ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: symrun_interp_fixpoint)
  moreover have ‚Äπ‚ãÇ ((ŒªŒ≥. ‚ü¶ Œ≥ ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m) ` set Œì) = ‚ãÇ ((ŒªŒ≥. ‚ü¶ Œ≥ ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m) ` set Œì')‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: assms)
  ultimately show ?thesis using symrun_interp_remdups_absorb by auto
qed

text‚Äπ
  The interpretation of contexts is contravariant with regard to set inclusion.
‚Ä∫
theorem symrun_interp_decreases_setinc:
  assumes ‚Äπset Œì ‚äÜ set Œì'‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚äá ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì' ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
proof -
  obtain Œì‚á©r where decompose: ‚Äπset (Œì @ Œì‚á©r) = set Œì'‚Ä∫ using assms by auto
  hence ‚Äπset (Œì @ Œì‚á©r) = set Œì'‚Ä∫ using assms by blast
  moreover have ‚Äπ(set Œì) ‚à™ (set Œì‚á©r) = set Œì'‚Ä∫ using assms decompose by auto
  moreover have ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì' ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì @ Œì‚á©r ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
    using symrun_interp_set_lifting decompose by blast
  moreover have ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì @ Œì‚á©r ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚à© ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©r ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
    by (simp add: symrun_interp_expansion)
  moreover have ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚äá ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚à© ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©r ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫ by simp
  ultimately show ?thesis by simp
qed

lemma symrun_interp_decreases_add_head:
  assumes ‚Äπset Œì ‚äÜ set Œì'‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ≥ # Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚äá ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œ≥ # Œì' ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
using symrun_interp_decreases_setinc assms by auto

lemma symrun_interp_decreases_add_tail:
  assumes ‚Äπset Œì ‚äÜ set Œì'‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì @ [Œ≥] ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚äá ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì' @ [Œ≥] ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
proof -
  from symrun_interp_decreases_setinc[OF assms] have ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì' ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚äÜ ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫ .
  thus ?thesis by (simp add: symrun_interp_expansion dual_order.trans)
qed

lemma symrun_interp_absorb1:
  assumes ‚Äπset Œì‚á©1 ‚äÜ set Œì‚á©2‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©1 @ Œì‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
by (simp add: Int_absorb1 symrun_interp_decreases_setinc
                          symrun_interp_expansion assms)

lemma symrun_interp_absorb2:
  assumes ‚Äπset Œì‚á©2 ‚äÜ set Œì‚á©1‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©1 @ Œì‚á©2 ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m = ‚ü¶‚ü¶ Œì‚á©1 ‚üß‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m‚Ä∫
using symrun_interp_absorb1 symrun_interp_commute assms by blast

end

Theory Operational

chapter ‚ÄπOperational Semantics‚Ä∫
text‚Äπ\label{chap:operational_semantics}‚Ä∫

theory Operational
imports
  SymbolicPrimitive

begin

text‚Äπ
  The operational semantics defines rules to build symbolic runs from a TESL 
  specification (a set of TESL formulae).
  Symbolic runs are described using the symbolic primitives presented in the 
  previous chapter.
  Therefore, the operational semantics compiles a set of constraints on runs, 
  as defined by the denotational semantics, into a set of symbolic constraints 
  on the instants of the runs. Concrete runs can then be obtained by solving the 
  constraints at each instant.
‚Ä∫

section‚ÄπOperational steps‚Ä∫

text ‚Äπ
  We introduce a notation to describe configurations:
  ‚ñ™ @{term ‚ÄπŒì‚Ä∫} is the context, the set of symbolic constraints on past instants of the run;
  ‚ñ™ @{term ‚Äπn‚Ä∫} is the index of the current instant, the present;
  ‚ñ™ @{term ‚ÄπŒ®‚Ä∫} is the TESL formula that must be satisfied at the current instant (present);
  ‚ñ™ @{term ‚ÄπŒ¶‚Ä∫} is the TESL formula that must be satisfied for the following instants (the future).
‚Ä∫
abbreviation uncurry_conf
  ::‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) system ‚áí instant_index ‚áí 'œÑ TESL_formula ‚áí 'œÑ TESL_formula
      ‚áí 'œÑ config‚Ä∫                                                  (‚Äπ_, _ ‚ä¢ _ ‚ñπ _‚Ä∫ 80)
where
  ‚ÄπŒì, n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ Œ¶ ‚â° (Œì, n, Œ®, Œ¶)‚Ä∫

text ‚Äπ
  The only introduction rule allows us to progress to the next instant 
  when there are no more constraints to satisfy for the present instant.
‚Ä∫
inductive operational_semantics_intro
  ::‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) config ‚áí 'œÑ config ‚áí bool‚Ä∫              (‚Äπ_ ‚Ü™‚á©i _‚Ä∫ 70)
where
  instant_i:
  ‚Äπ(Œì, n ‚ä¢ [] ‚ñπ Œ¶) ‚Ü™‚á©i  (Œì, Suc n ‚ä¢ Œ¶ ‚ñπ [])‚Ä∫

text ‚Äπ
  The elimination rules describe how TESL formulae for the present are transformed 
  into constraints on the past and on the future.
‚Ä∫
inductive operational_semantics_elim
  ::‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) config ‚áí 'œÑ config ‚áí bool‚Ä∫              (‚Äπ_ ‚Ü™‚á©e _‚Ä∫ 70)
where
  sporadic_on_e1:
‚Äï ‚ÄπA sporadic constraint can be ignored in the present and rejected into the future.‚Ä∫
  ‚Äπ(Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 sporadic œÑ on K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶)
     ‚Ü™‚á©e  (Œì, n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 sporadic œÑ on K‚á©2) # Œ¶))‚Ä∫
| sporadic_on_e2:
‚Äï ‚ÄπIt can also be handled in the present by making the clock tick and have 
  the expected time. Once it has been handled, it is no longer a constraint 
  to satisfy, so it disappears from the future.‚Ä∫
  ‚Äπ(Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 sporadic œÑ on K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶)
     ‚Ü™‚á©e  (((K‚á©1 ‚áë n) # (K‚á©2 ‚áì n @ œÑ) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ Œ¶)‚Ä∫
| tagrel_e:
‚Äï ‚ÄπA relation between time scales has to be obeyed at every instant.‚Ä∫
  ‚Äπ(Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((time-relation ‚åäK‚á©1, K‚á©2‚åã ‚àà R) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶)
     ‚Ü™‚á©e  (((‚åäœÑ‚á©v‚á©a‚á©r(K‚á©1, n), œÑ‚á©v‚á©a‚á©r(K‚á©2, n)‚åã ‚àà R) # Œì), n
              ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((time-relation ‚åäK‚á©1, K‚á©2‚åã ‚àà R) # Œ¶))‚Ä∫
| implies_e1:
‚Äï ‚ÄπAn implication can be handled in the present by forbidding a tick of the master
  clock. The implication is copied back into the future because it holds for 
  the whole run.‚Ä∫
  ‚Äπ(Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 implies K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶)
     ‚Ü™‚á©e  (((K‚á©1 ¬¨‚áë n) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 implies K‚á©2) # Œ¶))‚Ä∫
| implies_e2:
‚Äï ‚ÄπIt can also be handled in the present by making both the master and the slave
    clocks tick.‚Ä∫
  ‚Äπ(Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 implies K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶)
     ‚Ü™‚á©e  (((K‚á©1 ‚áë n) # (K‚á©2 ‚áë n) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 implies K‚á©2) # Œ¶))‚Ä∫
| implies_not_e1:
‚Äï ‚ÄπA negative implication can be handled in the present by forbidding a tick of 
  the master clock. The implication is copied back into the future because 
  it holds for the whole run.‚Ä∫
  ‚Äπ(Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 implies not K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶)
     ‚Ü™‚á©e  (((K‚á©1 ¬¨‚áë n) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 implies not K‚á©2) # Œ¶))‚Ä∫
| implies_not_e2:
‚Äï ‚ÄπIt can also be handled in the present by making the master clock ticks and 
    forbidding a tick on the slave clock.‚Ä∫
  ‚Äπ(Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 implies not K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶)
     ‚Ü™‚á©e  (((K‚á©1 ‚áë n) # (K‚á©2 ¬¨‚áë n) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 implies not K‚á©2) # Œ¶))‚Ä∫
| timedelayed_e1:
‚Äï ‚ÄπA timed delayed implication can be handled by forbidding a tick on 
    the master clock.‚Ä∫
  ‚Äπ(Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 time-delayed by Œ¥œÑ on K‚á©2 implies K‚á©3) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶)
     ‚Ü™‚á©e  (((K‚á©1 ¬¨‚áë n) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 time-delayed by Œ¥œÑ on K‚á©2 implies K‚á©3) # Œ¶))‚Ä∫
| timedelayed_e2:
‚Äï ‚ÄπIt can also be handled by making the master clock tick and adding a constraint 
    that makes the slave clock tick when the delay has elapsed on the measuring clock.‚Ä∫
  ‚Äπ(Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 time-delayed by Œ¥œÑ on K‚á©2 implies K‚á©3) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶)
     ‚Ü™‚á©e  (((K‚á©1 ‚áë n) # (K‚á©2 @ n ‚äï Œ¥œÑ ‚áí K‚á©3) # Œì), n
            ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 time-delayed by Œ¥œÑ on K‚á©2 implies K‚á©3) # Œ¶))‚Ä∫
| weakly_precedes_e:
‚Äï ‚ÄπA weak precedence relation has to hold at every instant.‚Ä∫
  ‚Äπ(Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 weakly precedes K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶)
     ‚Ü™‚á©e  (((‚åà#‚áß‚â§ K‚á©2 n, #‚áß‚â§ K‚á©1 n‚åâ ‚àà (Œª(x,y). x‚â§y)) # Œì), n
            ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 weakly precedes K‚á©2) # Œ¶))‚Ä∫
| strictly_precedes_e:
‚Äï ‚ÄπA strict precedence relation has to hold at every instant.‚Ä∫
  ‚Äπ(Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 strictly precedes K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶)
     ‚Ü™‚á©e  (((‚åà#‚áß‚â§ K‚á©2 n, #‚áß< K‚á©1 n‚åâ ‚àà (Œª(x,y). x‚â§y)) # Œì), n
            ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 strictly precedes K‚á©2) # Œ¶))‚Ä∫
| kills_e1:
‚Äï ‚ÄπA kill can be handled by forbidding a tick of the triggering clock.‚Ä∫
  ‚Äπ(Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 kills K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶)
     ‚Ü™‚á©e  (((K‚á©1 ¬¨‚áë n) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 kills K‚á©2) # Œ¶))‚Ä∫
| kills_e2:
‚Äï ‚ÄπIt can also be handled by making the triggering clock tick and by forbidding 
    any further tick of the killed clock.‚Ä∫
  ‚Äπ(Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 kills K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶)
     ‚Ü™‚á©e  (((K‚á©1 ‚áë n) # (K‚á©2 ¬¨‚áë ‚â• n) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 kills K‚á©2) # Œ¶))‚Ä∫

text ‚Äπ
  A step of the operational semantics is either the application of the introduction 
  rule or the application of an elimination rule.
‚Ä∫
inductive operational_semantics_step
  ::‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) config ‚áí 'œÑ config ‚áí bool‚Ä∫              (‚Äπ_ ‚Ü™ _‚Ä∫ 70)
where
  intro_part:
  ‚Äπ(Œì‚á©1, n‚á©1 ‚ä¢ Œ®‚á©1 ‚ñπ Œ¶‚á©1)  ‚Ü™‚á©i  (Œì‚á©2, n‚á©2 ‚ä¢ Œ®‚á©2 ‚ñπ Œ¶‚á©2)
    ‚üπ (Œì‚á©1, n‚á©1 ‚ä¢ Œ®‚á©1 ‚ñπ Œ¶‚á©1)  ‚Ü™  (Œì‚á©2, n‚á©2 ‚ä¢ Œ®‚á©2 ‚ñπ Œ¶‚á©2)‚Ä∫
| elims_part:
  ‚Äπ(Œì‚á©1, n‚á©1 ‚ä¢ Œ®‚á©1 ‚ñπ Œ¶‚á©1)  ‚Ü™‚á©e  (Œì‚á©2, n‚á©2 ‚ä¢ Œ®‚á©2 ‚ñπ Œ¶‚á©2)
    ‚üπ (Œì‚á©1, n‚á©1 ‚ä¢ Œ®‚á©1 ‚ñπ Œ¶‚á©1)  ‚Ü™  (Œì‚á©2, n‚á©2 ‚ä¢ Œ®‚á©2 ‚ñπ Œ¶‚á©2)‚Ä∫

text ‚Äπ
  We introduce notations for the reflexive transitive closure of the operational 
  semantic step, its transitive closure and its reflexive closure.
‚Ä∫
abbreviation operational_semantics_step_rtranclp
  ::‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) config ‚áí 'œÑ config ‚áí bool‚Ä∫              (‚Äπ_ ‚Ü™‚áß*‚áß* _‚Ä∫ 70)
where
  ‚Äπùíû‚á©1 ‚Ü™‚áß*‚áß* ùíû‚á©2 ‚â° operational_semantics_step‚áß*‚áß* ùíû‚á©1 ùíû‚á©2‚Ä∫

abbreviation operational_semantics_step_tranclp
  ::‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) config ‚áí 'œÑ config ‚áí bool‚Ä∫              (‚Äπ_ ‚Ü™‚áß+‚áß+ _‚Ä∫ 70)
where
  ‚Äπùíû‚á©1 ‚Ü™‚áß+‚áß+ ùíû‚á©2 ‚â° operational_semantics_step‚áß+‚áß+ ùíû‚á©1 ùíû‚á©2‚Ä∫

abbreviation operational_semantics_step_reflclp
  ::‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) config ‚áí 'œÑ config ‚áí bool‚Ä∫              (‚Äπ_ ‚Ü™‚áß=‚áß= _‚Ä∫ 70)
where
  ‚Äπùíû‚á©1 ‚Ü™‚áß=‚áß= ùíû‚á©2 ‚â° operational_semantics_step‚áß=‚áß= ùíû‚á©1 ùíû‚á©2‚Ä∫

abbreviation operational_semantics_step_relpowp
  ::‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) config ‚áí nat ‚áí 'œÑ config ‚áí bool‚Ä∫       (‚Äπ_ ‚Ü™‚áó_‚áñ _‚Ä∫ 70)
where
  ‚Äπùíû‚á©1 ‚Ü™‚áón‚áñ ùíû‚á©2 ‚â° (operational_semantics_step ^^ n) ùíû‚á©1 ùíû‚á©2‚Ä∫

definition operational_semantics_elim_inv
  ::‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) config ‚áí 'œÑ config ‚áí bool‚Ä∫              (‚Äπ_ ‚Ü™‚á©e‚áß‚Üê _‚Ä∫ 70)
where
  ‚Äπùíû‚á©1 ‚Ü™‚á©e‚áß‚Üê ùíû‚á©2 ‚â° ùíû‚á©2 ‚Ü™‚á©e ùíû‚á©1‚Ä∫


section‚ÄπBasic Lemmas‚Ä∫

text ‚Äπ
  If a configuration can be reached in @{term ‚Äπm‚Ä∫} steps from a configuration that 
  can be reached in @{term ‚Äπn‚Ä∫} steps from an original configuration, then it can be 
  reached in @{term ‚Äπn+m‚Ä∫} steps from the original configuration.
‚Ä∫
lemma operational_semantics_trans_generalized:
  assumes ‚Äπùíû‚á©1 ‚Ü™‚áón‚áñ ùíû‚á©2‚Ä∫
  assumes ‚Äπùíû‚á©2 ‚Ü™‚áóm‚áñ ùíû‚á©3‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπùíû‚á©1 ‚Ü™‚áón + m‚áñ ùíû‚á©3‚Ä∫
using relcompp.relcompI[of  ‚Äπoperational_semantics_step ^^ n‚Ä∫ _ _ 
                            ‚Äπoperational_semantics_step ^^ m‚Ä∫, OF assms]
by (simp add: relpowp_add) 

text ‚Äπ
  We consider the set of configurations that can be reached in one operational
  step from a given configuration.
‚Ä∫
abbreviation Cnext_solve
  ::‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) config ‚áí 'œÑ config set‚Ä∫ (‚Äπùíû‚á©n‚á©e‚á©x‚á©t _‚Ä∫)
where
  ‚Äπùíû‚á©n‚á©e‚á©x‚á©t ùíÆ ‚â° { ùíÆ'. ùíÆ ‚Ü™ ùíÆ' }‚Ä∫

text ‚Äπ
  Advancing to the next instant is possible when there are no more constraints 
  on the current instant.
‚Ä∫
lemma Cnext_solve_instant:
  ‚Äπ(ùíû‚á©n‚á©e‚á©x‚á©t (Œì, n ‚ä¢ [] ‚ñπ Œ¶)) ‚äá { Œì, Suc n ‚ä¢ Œ¶ ‚ñπ [] }‚Ä∫
by (simp add: operational_semantics_step.simps operational_semantics_intro.instant_i)

text ‚Äπ
  The following lemmas state that the configurations produced by the elimination 
  rules of the operational semantics belong to the configurations that can be 
  reached in one step.
‚Ä∫
lemma Cnext_solve_sporadicon:
  ‚Äπ(ùíû‚á©n‚á©e‚á©x‚á©t (Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 sporadic œÑ on K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶))
    ‚äá { Œì, n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 sporadic œÑ on K‚á©2) # Œ¶),
        ((K‚á©1 ‚áë n) # (K‚á©2 ‚áì n @ œÑ) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ Œ¶ }‚Ä∫
by (simp add: operational_semantics_step.simps
              operational_semantics_elim.sporadic_on_e1
              operational_semantics_elim.sporadic_on_e2)

lemma Cnext_solve_tagrel:
  ‚Äπ(ùíû‚á©n‚á©e‚á©x‚á©t (Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((time-relation ‚åäK‚á©1, K‚á©2‚åã ‚àà R) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶))
    ‚äá { ((‚åäœÑ‚á©v‚á©a‚á©r(K‚á©1, n), œÑ‚á©v‚á©a‚á©r(K‚á©2, n)‚åã ‚àà R) # Œì),n
          ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((time-relation ‚åäK‚á©1, K‚á©2‚åã ‚àà R) # Œ¶) }‚Ä∫
by (simp add: operational_semantics_step.simps operational_semantics_elim.tagrel_e)

lemma Cnext_solve_implies:
  ‚Äπ(ùíû‚á©n‚á©e‚á©x‚á©t (Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 implies K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶))
    ‚äá { ((K‚á©1 ¬¨‚áë n) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 implies K‚á©2) # Œ¶),
         ((K‚á©1 ‚áë n) # (K‚á©2 ‚áë n) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 implies K‚á©2) # Œ¶) }‚Ä∫
by (simp add: operational_semantics_step.simps operational_semantics_elim.implies_e1
              operational_semantics_elim.implies_e2)

lemma Cnext_solve_implies_not:
  ‚Äπ(ùíû‚á©n‚á©e‚á©x‚á©t (Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 implies not K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶))
    ‚äá { ((K‚á©1 ¬¨‚áë n) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 implies not K‚á©2) # Œ¶),
        ((K‚á©1 ‚áë n) # (K‚á©2 ¬¨‚áë n) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 implies not K‚á©2) # Œ¶) }‚Ä∫
by (simp add: operational_semantics_step.simps
              operational_semantics_elim.implies_not_e1
              operational_semantics_elim.implies_not_e2)

lemma Cnext_solve_timedelayed:
  ‚Äπ(ùíû‚á©n‚á©e‚á©x‚á©t (Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 time-delayed by Œ¥œÑ on K‚á©2 implies K‚á©3) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶))
    ‚äá { ((K‚á©1 ¬¨‚áë n) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 time-delayed by Œ¥œÑ on K‚á©2 implies K‚á©3) # Œ¶),
        ((K‚á©1 ‚áë n) # (K‚á©2 @ n ‚äï Œ¥œÑ ‚áí K‚á©3) # Œì), n
          ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 time-delayed by Œ¥œÑ on K‚á©2 implies K‚á©3) # Œ¶) }‚Ä∫
by (simp add: operational_semantics_step.simps
              operational_semantics_elim.timedelayed_e1
              operational_semantics_elim.timedelayed_e2)

lemma Cnext_solve_weakly_precedes:
  ‚Äπ(ùíû‚á©n‚á©e‚á©x‚á©t (Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 weakly precedes K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶))
    ‚äá { ((‚åà#‚áß‚â§ K‚á©2 n, #‚áß‚â§ K‚á©1 n‚åâ ‚àà (Œª(x,y). x‚â§y)) # Œì), n
          ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 weakly precedes K‚á©2) # Œ¶) }‚Ä∫
by (simp add: operational_semantics_step.simps
              operational_semantics_elim.weakly_precedes_e)

lemma Cnext_solve_strictly_precedes:
  ‚Äπ(ùíû‚á©n‚á©e‚á©x‚á©t (Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 strictly precedes K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶))
    ‚äá { ((‚åà#‚áß‚â§ K‚á©2 n, #‚áß< K‚á©1 n‚åâ ‚àà (Œª(x,y). x‚â§y)) # Œì), n
          ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 strictly precedes K‚á©2) # Œ¶) }‚Ä∫
by (simp add: operational_semantics_step.simps
              operational_semantics_elim.strictly_precedes_e)

lemma Cnext_solve_kills:
  ‚Äπ(ùíû‚á©n‚á©e‚á©x‚á©t (Œì, n ‚ä¢ ((K‚á©1 kills K‚á©2) # Œ®) ‚ñπ Œ¶))
    ‚äá { ((K‚á©1 ¬¨‚áë n) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 kills K‚á©2) # Œ¶),
        ((K‚á©1 ‚áë n) # (K‚á©2 ¬¨‚áë ‚â• n) # Œì), n ‚ä¢ Œ® ‚ñπ ((K‚á©1 kills K‚á©2) # Œ¶) }‚Ä∫
by (simp add: operational_semantics_step.simps operational_semantics_elim.kills_e1
              operational_semantics_elim.kills_e2)

text ‚Äπ
  An empty specification can be reduced to an empty specification for 
  an arbitrary number of steps.
‚Ä∫
lemma empty_spec_reductions:
  ‚Äπ([], 0 ‚ä¢ [] ‚ñπ []) ‚Ü™‚áók‚áñ ([], k ‚ä¢ [] ‚ñπ [])‚Ä∫
proof (induct k)
  case 0 thus ?case by simp
next
  case Suc thus ?case
    using instant_i operational_semantics_step.simps by fastforce 
qed

end

Theory Corecursive_Prop

(*chapter‚ÄπEquivalence of Operational and Denotational Semantics‚Ä∫*)
text‚Äπ\chapter[Semantics Equivalence]{Equivalence of the Operational and Denotational Semantics}‚Ä∫

theory Corecursive_Prop
  imports
    SymbolicPrimitive
    Operational
    Denotational

begin

section ‚ÄπStepwise denotational interpretation of TESL atoms‚Ä∫

text ‚Äπ
  In order to prove the equivalence of the denotational and operational semantics, 
  we need to be able to ignore the past (for which the constraints are encoded 
  in the context) and consider only the satisfaction of the constraints from
  a given instant index.
  For this purpose, we define an interpretation of TESL formulae for a suffix of a run.
  That interpretation is closely related to the denotational semantics as
  defined in the preceding chapters.
‚Ä∫
fun TESL_interpretation_atomic_stepwise
    :: ‚Äπ('œÑ::linordered_field) TESL_atomic ‚áí nat ‚áí 'œÑ run set‚Ä∫ (‚Äπ‚ü¶ _ ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• _‚áñ‚Ä∫)
where
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 sporadic œÑ on K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• i‚áñ =
      {œÅ. ‚àÉn‚â•i. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n K‚á©1) ‚àß time ((Rep_run œÅ) n K‚á©2) = œÑ}‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ time-relation ‚åäK‚á©1, K‚á©2‚åã ‚àà R ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• i‚áñ =
      {œÅ. ‚àÄn‚â•i. R (time ((Rep_run œÅ) n K‚á©1), time ((Rep_run œÅ) n K‚á©2))}‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ master implies slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• i‚áñ =
      {œÅ. ‚àÄn‚â•i. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n master) ‚ü∂ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n slave)}‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ master implies not slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• i‚áñ =
      {œÅ. ‚àÄn‚â•i. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n master) ‚ü∂ ¬¨ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n slave)}‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ master time-delayed by Œ¥œÑ on measuring implies slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• i‚áñ =
      {œÅ. ‚àÄn‚â•i. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n master) ‚ü∂
               (let measured_time = time ((Rep_run œÅ) n measuring) in
                ‚àÄm ‚â• n. first_time œÅ measuring m (measured_time + Œ¥œÑ)
                         ‚ü∂ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) m slave)
               )
      }‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 weakly precedes K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• i‚áñ =
      {œÅ. ‚àÄn‚â•i. (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©2 n) ‚â§ (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©1 n)}‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 strictly precedes K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• i‚áñ =
      {œÅ. ‚àÄn‚â•i. (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©2 n) ‚â§ (run_tick_count_strictly œÅ K‚á©1 n)}‚Ä∫
| ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 kills K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• i‚áñ =
      {œÅ. ‚àÄn‚â•i. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n K‚á©1) ‚ü∂ (‚àÄm‚â•n. ¬¨ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) m K‚á©2))}‚Ä∫

text ‚Äπ
  The denotational interpretation of TESL formulae can be unfolded into the 
  stepwise interpretation.
‚Ä∫
lemma TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_sporadicon:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 sporadic œÑ on K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ãÉ {Y. ‚àÉn::nat. Y = ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 sporadic œÑ on K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ}‚Ä∫
by auto

lemma TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_tagrelgen:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ time-relation ‚åäK‚á©1, K‚á©2‚åã ‚àà R ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L
    = ‚ãÇ {Y. ‚àÉn::nat. Y = ‚ü¶ time-relation ‚åäK‚á©1, K‚á©2‚åã ‚àà R ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ}‚Ä∫
by auto

lemma TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_implies:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ master implies slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L
    = ‚ãÇ {Y. ‚àÉn::nat. Y = ‚ü¶ master implies slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ}‚Ä∫
by auto

lemma TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_implies_not:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ master implies not slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L
    = ‚ãÇ {Y. ‚àÉn::nat. Y = ‚ü¶ master implies not slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ}‚Ä∫
by auto

lemma TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_timedelayed:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ master time-delayed by Œ¥œÑ on measuring implies slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L
    = ‚ãÇ {Y. ‚àÉn::nat.
          Y = ‚ü¶ master time-delayed by Œ¥œÑ on measuring implies slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ}‚Ä∫
by auto

lemma TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_weakly_precedes:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 weakly precedes K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L
    = ‚ãÇ {Y. ‚àÉn::nat. Y = ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 weakly precedes K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ}‚Ä∫
by auto

lemma TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_strictly_precedes:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 strictly precedes K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L
    = ‚ãÇ {Y. ‚àÉn::nat. Y = ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 strictly precedes K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ}‚Ä∫
by auto

lemma TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_kills:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ master kills slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ãÇ {Y. ‚àÉn::nat. Y = ‚ü¶ master kills slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ}‚Ä∫
by auto

text ‚Äπ
  Positive atomic formulae (the ones that create ticks from nothing) are unfolded
  as the union of the stepwise interpretations.
‚Ä∫
theorem TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_positive_atoms:
  assumes ‚Äπpositive_atom œÜ‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶ œÜ::'œÑ::linordered_field TESL_atomic ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L
            = ‚ãÉ {Y. ‚àÉn::nat. Y = ‚ü¶ œÜ ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ}‚Ä∫
proof -
  from positive_atom.elims(2)[OF assms]
    obtain u v w where ‚ÄπœÜ = (u sporadic v on w)‚Ä∫ by blast
  with TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_sporadicon show ?thesis by simp
qed

text ‚Äπ
  Negative atomic formulae are unfolded
  as the intersection of the stepwise interpretations.
‚Ä∫
theorem TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_negative_atoms:
  assumes ‚Äπ¬¨ positive_atom œÜ‚Ä∫
    shows ‚Äπ‚ü¶ œÜ ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L = ‚ãÇ {Y. ‚àÉn::nat. Y = ‚ü¶ œÜ ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ}‚Ä∫
proof (cases œÜ)
  case SporadicOn thus ?thesis using assms by simp
next
  case TagRelation
    thus ?thesis using TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_tagrelgen by simp
next
  case Implies
    thus ?thesis using TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_implies by simp
next
  case ImpliesNot
    thus ?thesis using TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_implies_not by simp
next
  case TimeDelayedBy
    thus ?thesis using TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_timedelayed by simp
next
  case WeaklyPrecedes
    thus ?thesis
      using TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_weakly_precedes by simp
next
  case StrictlyPrecedes
    thus ?thesis
      using TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_strictly_precedes by simp
next
  case Kills
    thus ?thesis
      using TESL_interp_unfold_stepwise_kills by simp
qed

text ‚Äπ
  Some useful lemmas for reasoning on properties of sequences.
‚Ä∫
lemma forall_nat_expansion:
  ‚Äπ(‚àÄn ‚â• (n‚á©0::nat). P n) = (P n‚á©0 ‚àß (‚àÄn ‚â• Suc n‚á©0. P n))‚Ä∫
proof -
  have ‚Äπ(‚àÄn ‚â• (n‚á©0::nat). P n) = (‚àÄn. (n = n‚á©0 ‚à® n > n‚á©0) ‚ü∂ P n)‚Ä∫
    using le_less by blast
  also have ‚Äπ... = (P n‚á©0 ‚àß (‚àÄn > n‚á©0. P n))‚Ä∫ by blast
  finally show ?thesis using Suc_le_eq by simp
qed

lemma exists_nat_expansion:
  ‚Äπ(‚àÉn ‚â• (n‚á©0::nat). P n) = (P n‚á©0 ‚à® (‚àÉn ‚â• Suc n‚á©0. P n))‚Ä∫
proof -
  have ‚Äπ(‚àÉn ‚â• (n‚á©0::nat). P n) = (‚àÉn. (n = n‚á©0 ‚à® n > n‚á©0) ‚àß P n)‚Ä∫
    using le_less by blast
  also have ‚Äπ... = (‚àÉn. (P n‚á©0) ‚à® (n > n‚á©0 ‚àß P n))‚Ä∫ by blast
  finally show ?thesis using Suc_le_eq by simp
qed

lemma forall_nat_set_suc:‚Äπ{x. ‚àÄm ‚â• n. P x m} = {x. P x n} ‚à© {x. ‚àÄm ‚â• Suc n. P x m}‚Ä∫
proof
  { fix x assume h:‚Äπx ‚àà {x. ‚àÄm ‚â• n. P x m}‚Ä∫
    hence ‚ÄπP x n‚Ä∫ by simp
    moreover from h have ‚Äπx ‚àà {x. ‚àÄm ‚â• Suc n. P x m}‚Ä∫ by simp
    ultimately have ‚Äπx ‚àà {x. P x n} ‚à© {x. ‚àÄm ‚â• Suc n. P x m}‚Ä∫ by simp
  } thus ‚Äπ{x. ‚àÄm ‚â• n. P x m} ‚äÜ {x. P x n} ‚à© {x. ‚àÄm ‚â• Suc n. P x m}‚Ä∫ ..
next
  { fix x  assume h:‚Äπx ‚àà {x. P x n} ‚à© {x. ‚àÄm ‚â• Suc n. P x m}‚Ä∫
    hence ‚ÄπP x n‚Ä∫ by simp
    moreover from h have ‚Äπ‚àÄm ‚â• Suc n. P x m‚Ä∫ by simp
    ultimately have ‚Äπ‚àÄm ‚â• n. P x m‚Ä∫ using forall_nat_expansion by blast
    hence ‚Äπx ‚àà {x. ‚àÄm ‚â• n. P x m}‚Ä∫ by simp
  } thus ‚Äπ{x. P x n} ‚à© {x. ‚àÄm ‚â• Suc n. P x m} ‚äÜ {x. ‚àÄm ‚â• n. P x m}‚Ä∫ ..
qed

lemma exists_nat_set_suc:‚Äπ{x. ‚àÉm ‚â• n. P x m} = {x. P x n} ‚à™ {x. ‚àÉm ‚â• Suc n. P x m}‚Ä∫
proof
  { fix x assume h:‚Äπx ‚àà {x. ‚àÉm ‚â• n. P x m}‚Ä∫
    hence ‚Äπx ‚àà {x. ‚àÉm. (m = n ‚à® m ‚â• Suc n) ‚àß P x m}‚Ä∫
      using Suc_le_eq antisym_conv2 by fastforce
    hence ‚Äπx ‚àà {x. P x n} ‚à™ {x. ‚àÉm ‚â• Suc n. P x m}‚Ä∫ by blast
  } thus ‚Äπ{x. ‚àÉm ‚â• n. P x m} ‚äÜ {x. P x n} ‚à™ {x. ‚àÉm ‚â• Suc n. P x m}‚Ä∫ ..
next
  { fix x  assume h:‚Äπx ‚àà {x. P x n} ‚à™ {x. ‚àÉm ‚â• Suc n. P x m}‚Ä∫
    hence ‚Äπx ‚àà {x. ‚àÉm ‚â• n. P x m}‚Ä∫ using Suc_leD by blast
  } thus ‚Äπ{x. P x n} ‚à™ {x. ‚àÉm ‚â• Suc n. P x m} ‚äÜ {x. ‚àÉm ‚â• n. P x m}‚Ä∫ ..
qed

section ‚ÄπCoinduction Unfolding Properties‚Ä∫

text ‚Äπ
  The following lemmas show how  to shorten a suffix, i.e. to unfold one instant 
  in the construction of a run. They correspond to the rules of the operational 
  semantics.
‚Ä∫
lemma TESL_interp_stepwise_sporadicon_coind_unfold:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 sporadic œÑ on K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ =
    ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 ‚áë n ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚à© ‚ü¶ K‚á©2 ‚áì n @ œÑ ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m        ‚Äï ‚Äπrule @{term sporadic_on_e2}‚Ä∫
    ‚à™ ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 sporadic œÑ on K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• Suc n‚áñ‚Ä∫   ‚Äï ‚Äπrule @{term sporadic_on_e1}‚Ä∫
unfolding TESL_interpretation_atomic_stepwise.simps(1)
          symbolic_run_interpretation_primitive.simps(1,6)
using exists_nat_set_suc[of ‚Äπn‚Ä∫ ‚ÄπŒªœÅ n. hamlet (Rep_run œÅ n K‚á©1)
                                     ‚àß time (Rep_run œÅ n K‚á©2) = œÑ‚Ä∫]
by (simp add: Collect_conj_eq)


lemma TESL_interp_stepwise_tagrel_coind_unfold:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ time-relation ‚åäK‚á©1, K‚á©2‚åã ‚àà R ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ =        ‚Äï ‚Äπrule @{term tagrel_e}‚Ä∫
     ‚ü¶ ‚åäœÑ‚á©v‚á©a‚á©r(K‚á©1, n), œÑ‚á©v‚á©a‚á©r(K‚á©2, n)‚åã ‚àà R ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m
     ‚à© ‚ü¶ time-relation ‚åäK‚á©1, K‚á©2‚åã ‚àà R ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• Suc n‚áñ‚Ä∫
proof -
  have ‚Äπ{œÅ. ‚àÄm‚â•n. R (time ((Rep_run œÅ) m K‚á©1), time ((Rep_run œÅ) m K‚á©2))}
       = {œÅ. R (time ((Rep_run œÅ) n K‚á©1), time ((Rep_run œÅ) n K‚á©2))}
       ‚à© {œÅ. ‚àÄm‚â•Suc n. R (time ((Rep_run œÅ) m K‚á©1), time ((Rep_run œÅ) m K‚á©2))}‚Ä∫
    using forall_nat_set_suc[of ‚Äπn‚Ä∫ ‚ÄπŒªx y. R (time ((Rep_run x) y K‚á©1),
                                       time ((Rep_run x) y K‚á©2))‚Ä∫] by simp
  thus ?thesis by auto
qed

lemma TESL_interp_stepwise_implies_coind_unfold:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ master implies slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ =
     (   ‚ü¶ master ¬¨‚áë n ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m                     ‚Äï ‚Äπrule @{term implies_e1}‚Ä∫
       ‚à™ ‚ü¶ master ‚áë n ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚à© ‚ü¶ slave ‚áë n ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m)  ‚Äï ‚Äπrule @{term implies_e2}‚Ä∫
     ‚à© ‚ü¶ master implies slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• Suc n‚áñ‚Ä∫
proof -
  have ‚Äπ{œÅ. ‚àÄm‚â•n. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) m master) ‚ü∂ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) m slave)}
        = {œÅ. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n master) ‚ü∂ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n slave)}
        ‚à© {œÅ. ‚àÄm‚â•Suc n. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) m master)
                     ‚ü∂ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) m slave)}‚Ä∫
    using forall_nat_set_suc[of ‚Äπn‚Ä∫ ‚ÄπŒªx y. hamlet ((Rep_run x) y master)
                                ‚ü∂ hamlet ((Rep_run x) y slave)‚Ä∫] by simp
  thus ?thesis by auto
qed

lemma TESL_interp_stepwise_implies_not_coind_unfold:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ master implies not slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ =
     (    ‚ü¶ master ¬¨‚áë n ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m                       ‚Äï ‚Äπrule @{term implies_not_e1}‚Ä∫
        ‚à™ ‚ü¶ master ‚áë n ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚à© ‚ü¶ slave ¬¨‚áë n ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m)  ‚Äï ‚Äπrule @{term implies_not_e2}‚Ä∫
     ‚à© ‚ü¶ master implies not slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• Suc n‚áñ‚Ä∫
proof -
  have ‚Äπ{œÅ. ‚àÄm‚â•n. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) m master) ‚ü∂ ¬¨ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) m slave)}
       = {œÅ. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n master) ‚ü∂ ¬¨ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n slave)}
          ‚à© {œÅ. ‚àÄm‚â•Suc n. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) m master)
                     ‚ü∂ ¬¨ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) m slave)}‚Ä∫
    using forall_nat_set_suc[of ‚Äπn‚Ä∫ ‚ÄπŒªx y. hamlet ((Rep_run x) y master)
                               ‚ü∂ ¬¨hamlet ((Rep_run x) y slave)‚Ä∫] by simp
  thus ?thesis by auto
qed

lemma TESL_interp_stepwise_timedelayed_coind_unfold:
  ‚Äπ‚ü¶ master time-delayed by Œ¥œÑ on measuring implies slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ =
     (     ‚ü¶ master ¬¨‚áë n ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m               ‚Äï ‚Äπrule @{term timedelayed_e1}‚Ä∫
        ‚à™ (‚ü¶ master ‚áë n ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚à© ‚ü¶ measuring @ n ‚äï Œ¥œÑ ‚áí slave ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m))
                                             ‚Äï ‚Äπrule @{term timedelayed_e2}‚Ä∫
     ‚à© ‚ü¶ master time-delayed by Œ¥œÑ on measuring implies slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• Suc n‚áñ‚Ä∫
proof -
  let ?prop = ‚ÄπŒªœÅ m. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) m master) ‚ü∂
                 (let measured_time = time ((Rep_run œÅ) m measuring) in
                  ‚àÄp ‚â• m. first_time œÅ measuring p (measured_time + Œ¥œÑ)
                           ‚ü∂ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) p slave))‚Ä∫
  have ‚Äπ{œÅ. ‚àÄm ‚â• n. ?prop œÅ m} = {œÅ. ?prop œÅ n} ‚à© {œÅ. ‚àÄm ‚â• Suc n. ?prop œÅ m}‚Ä∫
    using forall_nat_set_suc[of ‚Äπn‚Ä∫ ?prop] by blast
  also have ‚Äπ... = {œÅ. ?prop œÅ n}
              ‚à© ‚ü¶ master time-delayed by Œ¥œÑ on measuring implies slave ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• Suc n‚áñ‚Ä∫
    by simp
  finally show ?thesis by auto
qed

lemma TESL_interp_stepwise_weakly_precedes_coind_unfold:
   ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 weakly precedes K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ =                 ‚Äï ‚Äπrule @{term weakly_precedes_e}‚Ä∫
      ‚ü¶ (‚åà#‚áß‚â§ K‚á©2 n, #‚áß‚â§ K‚á©1 n‚åâ ‚àà (Œª(x,y). x‚â§y)) ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m 
      ‚à© ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 weakly precedes K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• Suc n‚áñ‚Ä∫
proof -
  have ‚Äπ{œÅ. ‚àÄp‚â•n. (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©2 p) ‚â§ (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©1 p)}
         = {œÅ. (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©2 n) ‚â§ (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©1 n)}
         ‚à© {œÅ. ‚àÄp‚â•Suc n. (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©2 p) ‚â§ (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©1 p)}‚Ä∫
    using forall_nat_set_suc[of ‚Äπn‚Ä∫ ‚ÄπŒªœÅ n. (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©2 n)
                                  ‚â§ (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©1 n)‚Ä∫]
    by simp
  thus ?thesis by auto
qed

lemma TESL_interp_stepwise_strictly_precedes_coind_unfold:
   ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 strictly precedes K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ =               ‚Äï ‚Äπrule @{term strictly_precedes_e}‚Ä∫
      ‚ü¶ (‚åà#‚áß‚â§ K‚á©2 n, #‚áß< K‚á©1 n‚åâ ‚àà (Œª(x,y). x‚â§y)) ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m
      ‚à© ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 strictly precedes K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• Suc n‚áñ‚Ä∫
proof -
  have ‚Äπ{œÅ. ‚àÄp‚â•n. (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©2 p) ‚â§ (run_tick_count_strictly œÅ K‚á©1 p)}
         = {œÅ. (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©2 n) ‚â§ (run_tick_count_strictly œÅ K‚á©1 n)}
         ‚à© {œÅ. ‚àÄp‚â•Suc n. (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©2 p) ‚â§ (run_tick_count_strictly œÅ K‚á©1 p)}‚Ä∫
    using forall_nat_set_suc[of ‚Äπn‚Ä∫ ‚ÄπŒªœÅ n. (run_tick_count œÅ K‚á©2 n)
                                  ‚â§ (run_tick_count_strictly œÅ K‚á©1 n)‚Ä∫]
    by simp
  thus ?thesis by auto
qed

lemma TESL_interp_stepwise_kills_coind_unfold:
   ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 kills K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ =
      (   ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 ¬¨‚áë n ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m                        ‚Äï ‚Äπrule @{term kills_e1}‚Ä∫
        ‚à™ ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 ‚áë n ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m ‚à© ‚ü¶ K‚á©2 ¬¨‚áë ‚â• n ‚üß‚á©p‚á©r‚á©i‚á©m)    ‚Äï ‚Äπrule @{term kills_e2}‚Ä∫
      ‚à© ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 kills K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• Suc n‚áñ‚Ä∫
proof -
  let ?kills = ‚ÄπŒªn œÅ. ‚àÄp‚â•n. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) p K‚á©1)
                             ‚ü∂ (‚àÄm‚â•p. ¬¨ hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) m K‚á©2))‚Ä∫
  let ?ticks = ‚ÄπŒªn œÅ c. hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) n c)‚Ä∫
  let ?dead = ‚ÄπŒªn œÅ c. ‚àÄm ‚â• n. ¬¨hamlet ((Rep_run œÅ) m c)‚Ä∫
  have ‚Äπ‚ü¶ K‚á©1 kills K‚á©2 ‚üß‚á©T‚á©E‚á©S‚á©L‚áó‚â• n‚áñ = {œÅ. ?kills n œÅ}‚Ä∫ by simp
  also have ‚Äπ... = ({œÅ. ¬¨ ?ticks n œÅ K‚á©1}  ‚à© {œÅ. ?kills (Suc n) œÅ})
                 ‚à™ ({œÅ. ?ticks n œÅ K‚á©1} ‚à© {œÅ. ?dead n œÅ K‚á©2})‚Ä∫
  proof
    { fix œÅ::‚Äπ'œÑ::linordered_field run‚Ä∫
      assume ‚ÄπœÅ ‚àà {œÅ. ?kills n œÅ}‚Ä∫
      hence ‚Äπ?kills n œÅ‚Ä∫ by simp
      hence ‚Äπ(?ticks n œÅ K‚á©1 ‚àß ?dead n œÅ K‚á©2) ‚à® (¬¨?ticks n œÅ K‚á©1 ‚àß ?kills (Suc n) œÅ)‚Ä∫
        using Suc_leD by blast
      hence ‚ÄπœÅ ‚àà ({œÅ. ?ticks n œÅ K‚á©1} ‚à© {œÅ. ?dead n œÅ K‚á©2})
               ‚à™ ({œÅ. ¬¨ ?ticks n œÅ K‚á©1} ‚à© {œÅ. ?kills (Suc n) œÅ})‚Ä∫
        by blast
    } thus ‚Äπ{œÅ. ?kills n œÅ}
